div.head: The second Part of If you know not mee, you know no bodie: With the building of the Exchange.

sp.stage: Enter one of Greshams Factors and a Barbary Marchant.

sp.speaker: Factor.
sp.l: MY Master sir, requests your companie,
About confirming certaine couenants
Touching your last nights conference.

sp.speaker: Marchant.
sp.l: The Sugars.
Beleeue me, to his credite be it spoke,
Hee is a man of heedfull prouidence,
And one that by innatiue courtesie
Winnes loue from Strangers, be it without offence,
How are his present fortunes reckoned?

sp.speaker: Fact.
sp.l: Neither to flatter nor detract from him,
He is a Marchant of good estimate,
Care how to get, and fore-cast to encrease,
(If so they be accounted) be his faults.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: They are especiall vertues, being cleare
From auarice and base extortion.
But here he comes: Good day, to M. Gresham,
You keepe your word.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Else should I ill deserue
The title that I weare, a Marchants tongue
Should not strike false.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What thinke you of my proffer,
Touching the Sugar?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: I be thought my selfe
Both of the gaine and losses incident,
And this I tak't was the whole circumstance:
It was my motion and I thinke your promise,
To get me a seald Patent from your king
For all your Barbarie Sugar at a price,
During the kings life; and for his princely loue,
I am to send him threescore thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.l: T'was so condition'd, and to that effect
His highnesse promise is alreadie past,
And if you dare giue credite to my trust,
Send but your priuate letters to your Factor,
That deales for your affaires in Barbarie,
His Maiestie shall either seale your Patent,
Or ile returne the money to your Factor.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: As much as I desire; pray sir draw neere
And taste a cup of wine, whilst I consider
And throughly scan such accidentall doubts,
As may concerne a matter of such moment.

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.l: At your best leysure.

sp.speaker: Gresh:
sp.l: Ile resolue you straight.
Bethinke thee Gresham, threescore thousand pounds
A good round summe: let not the hope of gaine
Draw thee to losse. I am to haue a Pattent
For all the Barbarie Sugars at a rate,
The gaine cleers halfe in halfe, but then the hazard:
My terme continues during the kings life,
The King may die before my first returne,
Then wheres my Cash? why, so the King may liue
These 40. yeares, then where is Greshams gaine:
It stands in this as in all ventures else
Doutfull, no more, ile through what ere it cost.
So much cleere gaine, or so much coyne cleere lost.
Within there ho.

sp.speaker: Fact:
sp.l: At hand sir, did you call?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: How thriues our Cash? what is it wel increast?
I speake like one that must be forst to borrow.

sp.speaker: 1. Fact.
sp.l: Your worships merrie.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Merry, tell me knaue,
Dost not thou think that three score thousand pounds,
Would make an honest Marchant try his friends?

sp.speaker: Fact.
sp.l: Yes, by my faith sir, but you haue a friend
Would not see you stand out for twise the summe.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Praise God for all, but what's the common rumor
Touching my bargaine with the King of Barbarie?

sp.speaker: 1. Fact.
sp.l: Tis held your credit, and your Countries honour,
That being but a Marchant of the Cittie,
And taken in a manner vnprouided,
You should vpon a meere presumption
And naked promise, part with so much Cash,
Which the best Marchants both in Spaine and France,
Denyed to venter on.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Good: but withall,
What doe they thinke in generall of the Bargaine?

sp.speaker: 1. Fact.
sp.l: That if the King confirme and seale your Pattent,
London will yeelde you partners ynow.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: I thinke no lesse: Goe fit you for the sea,
I meane to send you into Barbarie:
You vnto Venice, You to Portingall,
Prouide you presently: where much is spent,
Some must be got, thrift should be prouident:
Come hether Cosin, all the rest depart.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: I had as good depart too, for heele ring a peale in mine
T'will sound worse then a passing bell. (care,

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: I haue tane note of your bad husbandrie,
Carelesse respect, and prodigall expence,
And out of my experience counsell you.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: And I hope good Vncle, you thinke, I am as readie to take good counsell, as you to giue it, & I doubt not, but to cleere, my selfe of all obiections that foule-mouthed envie shall intimate against me.

sp.speaker: Gres.
sp.l: How can you satisfie the great complaint
Preferd against you by old Mistresse Blunt.
A woman of approued honestie.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: That's true, her honestie hath beene prooued ofter then once or twice: but doe you know her Vncle? are you inward with her course of life, shee's a common midwife for trade-falne virginitie, there are more maidenheads chargde and dischargde in her house in a yeare, then peeces at the Artillerie yard.

sp.speaker: Gres.
sp.l: She bring sin further proofe, that you miscal'd her.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: I neuer cal'd her out of name, by this hand Vncle, to my remembrance:

sp.speaker: Gres.
sp.l: No: she sayes you cald her Bawde.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: True; and I haue known her answere too't a thousand times; tut Vncle tis her name, and I know who gaue it her too, by the same token her Godfather gaue her a bowd angell standing at the doo re which she hath kept time out a minde.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Antonio reports you loue his wife.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Loue, why alas, Vncle, I hold it percell of my dutie to loue my neighbours, and should I hate his wife, no man would hold me a fit member for a common wealth.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: He hates you fort.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Why, ahlas Vncle, that's not my fault, ile loue him nerethelesse, you know we are commanded to loue our enemies, and though he would see me hang'd, yet will I loue his wife.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: He told me, you bestow'd a gowne of a strumpet.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Why, ahlas Vncle, the poore whore went naked, and you know the text commandes vs to cloath the naked, and deeds of mercie be imputed to vs for faults, God helpe the elect.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Well, if your prodigall expences be aym'd
At any vertuous and religious end,
Tis the more tollerable, and I am proud
You can so probably excuse your selfe.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Well Vncle to approoue my wordes, as indeed good words without deeds are like your greene fig-tree without fruit. I haue sworne my selfe to a more conformable and strikt course of life.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Well Cosin, hoping youle prooue a new man.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: A new man, what else Vncle, Ile be a newe man from the top to toe, or ile want of my will: Instead of Tennis-Court, my morning Exercise shalbe at Saint Antlms: ile leaue Ordinaries, and to the ende I may forsweare Dicing and Drabbing, keepe me more short Vncle, onely allow me good apparell, good Ragges ile stand too't are better then seuen yeares prentiship, for theyle make a man free of any, nay of all Companies without Indenture, Fathers coppie, or any help whatsoeuer, but I see my error, wilde Youth must be bridled, keepe mee short good Vncle.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: On these presumptions ile apparel thee,
And to confirme this resolution,
I will preferre you vnto Master Hobson,
A man of a well knowne discretion.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Any thing good Vncle, I haue seru'd my prentiship alreadie, but binde me againe and I shall be content, and tis but reason neither, send me to the Conduit with the water-tankard, ile beate Linnen, Bucks, or any thing to redeeme my negligence.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Your education challenge more respect.
The Factor dealt for him in France, is dead.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: And you intend to send me in his roome,

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: I doe indeede.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: I tis well done Vncle, and t'will not bee amisse in pollicie to doe so: the onely way to curbe a dissolute youth as I am, is to send him from his acquaintance, and therefore send mee farre inough good Vncle, send mee into France and spare not, and if that reclaime me not, giue me ore as one past all goodnes.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Now afore God my thoughts were much against him,
And my intent was to haue chid him roundly,
But his submissiue recantation.
Hath made me friends with him, Come follow me,
Ile doe thee good, and that immediately.

sp.speaker: Iohn:
sp.p: Thanke you good Vncle, youle send mee into France, all Forboone: and I doe not shew you the right tricke of a Cosin afore I leaue England, ile giue you leaue to call me Cut, and cosen me of my patrimonie as you haue done.
sp.stage: Enter Hobsons prentises and a boy.

sp.speaker: 1. Prent.
sp.p:
Prethee fellow Goodman, set foorth the ware, and
looke to the shop a little, Ile but drinke a cuppe of wine with a Customer at the Rose and Crowne in the Poultrie, and come againe presently.

sp.speaker: 2. Pren.
sp.p: Foote I cannot, I must needes step to the Dagger in Cheape to send a Letter into the Countrie vnto my father, stand by, you are the yougest prentise, looke you to the shop.
sp.l: Where be these varlets, bones a me, at Tauerne?
Knaues, villaines, spend goods, foote my Customers
Must either serue themselues, or packe vnseru'd.
Now they peepe like Italian pantelownes
Behind an Arras, but ile start you knaues,
I haue a shooing-horne to draw on your liquor,
What say you to a peece of a salt Eele?
Come forth you hangdogs, bones a me the knaues
Fleere in my face, they know me to too well,
I talke and prate, and lay't not on their iackes,
And the proud iackes care not a figge for me:
But bones a me, ile turne another leafe.
Where haue you beene sir?

sp.speaker: 1. Pren.
sp.l: An honest Customer
Requested me, to drinke a pint of wine.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Bones a me, must your crimson throat
Be scowr'd with wine? your master's glad of beere:
But youle die banquerouts, knaues, and banquerouts.
And where haue you beene?

sp.speaker: 2. Pren.
sp.l: At breakfast with a Dagger pie sir.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: A Dagger Pie! vd's daggers death, these knaues
Set cocke a hope, but Hobson payes for all.
But bones a me, knaues either mend your manners.
Leaue Alehouses, tauernes, and the tipling mates,
Your Punkes, and cocatrices, or ile clappe ye
Close vp in Bride well, bones of me Ile doo't,

sp.speaker: 2. Pren.
sp.l: Beseech you sir, pardon this first offence.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: First, bones a God, why tis your common course,
And you must needes be gusling, goe by turnes,
One to the Alehouse, and two keepe the shop.

sp.speaker: 2. Pren.
sp.l: It shall be done sir, how much ware youll you haue?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Fiue pounds worth in such Commodities,
as I bespoke last night.

sp.speaker: 1. Pren.
sp.l: They are readie sorted.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: God blesse you M. Hobson.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Bones a god, knaue, th'art welcome what's the newes
At bawdie Barnewell, and at Sturbridge Fayre?
What, haue your London wenches any trading?

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: After the old sort sir, they visite the Toulebooth, and the
Bulring still.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Good girles, they doe their kinde, what your packes emptie?
Good newes, a signe you bring your purses full,
And bones a God, full purses must be welcome:
Sort out their wares: welcome's your due:
Pay the old debt, and penne and incke for newe.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: We haue for you sir, as white as Beares teeth.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Bones a god, knaues you are welcome, but what newes?
What newes i'the Countrey? what Commodities
Are most respected with your countrie Girles?

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p: Faith sir, our Countrey girles are a kin to your London Courtiers, euery month sicke of a new fashion, the horning buske and silken bridelaces are in good request with the Parsons wife, your huge poking sticke, and french perewig, with Chamber-maides, and waiting-gentlewomen, now your Puritans poker is not so huge, but somewhat longer, a long slender poking sticke is the all in all with your Suffolke Puritane, your silkband, halfe farthingales, and changeable Fore-parts are common, not a wench of thirteene but weares a changeable forepart.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: An ancient wearing: ther's some changeable stuffe
Has beene a weare with women, time out of minde.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p: Besides sir, many of our yong married men, haue tane an order to weare yellow Garters, Points, & Shootyings, and us thought, yellow will grow a custome.

sp.speaker: Hob:
sp.l: T'as beene vsde long at London.

sp.speaker: Tow.
sp.p:
And tis thought t'will come in request in the Countrey
too, t'is a fashion, that three or foure yong wenches haue promis'd me their husbands shall weare, or theyle misse of their markes: then your maske, silke-lace, wash't Gloues, carnation girdles, and buske-point sutable, as common as Coales from New-castle, you shall not haue a Kitchin-maide scrape trenchers without her wash't Gloues, a Darie-wench will not ride to market to sell her Butter-milke, without her maske and her buske.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Still a good hearing, let the countrey pay
Well for their pride, tis gratis here at London,
And that's the cause tis growne so generall.
But feede their humours, and do not spare,
Bring Countrey-money for our London ware.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Where's M. Hobson, cry you mercie sir.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: No harme good M. Gresham, pray draw neere:
Ile but dispatch a fewe olde Customers,
And bend a present eare to your discourse.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: At your best leysure.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Nay my taske is done:
O M. Gresham t'was a golden world
When we were Boyes, an honest Countrey-yeoman,
Such as our fathers were, God rest their soules
Would were white Karfie: bones a me you knaues,
Stooles for these Gentlemen, your worships welcome.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: You know my businesse.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: About your kinsman,
He shall be welcome: beseech you Gentlemen
Lesse of your curtesie: when shall we see the Youth?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Why this is he.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Which, bones a me man, which?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Why this.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Which, where, what this yong gentleman!
Bones a me man, hee's not for Hobsons turne.
He lookes more like my Master then my seruant.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: I must confesse he is a Gentleman,
And my neere kinsman: were he myne owne childe,
His seruice should be yours.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: I thanke you for't,
And for your sake ile giue him entertainment?
But Gentleman if you become my man,
You must become more ciuile: bones a me,
What a curld pate is here? I must ha'te off,
You see my Liuerie, Hobsons men are knowne
By their Freeze Coates: and you will dwell with me,
You must be plaine, and leaue of brauerie.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: I hope sir to put on such ciuill conformitie, as you shall not repent my entertainment.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Pray God it prooue so.

sp.speaker: Gresh:
sp.l: If he doe respect
an Vncles loue, let him be diligent.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: well, M. Gresham, partly for your loue,
And chiefly to supply my present want,
Because you say your kinsman is well seene
Both in languages and factorship,
I doe intend to send him into France,
In trust both with my Marchandzies and my Cash.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: And if I take not order to cashier that and myselfe too, a pox of all French-farthingales.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: How stand you minded to your Masters motion?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Somewhat vnwilling to leaue my acquaintance, but good Vncle, I know you send me out of loue, and I hope t'will be a meanes to call me home the sooner.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Pray God it may.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Ile want of my will else, Ile play a Marchants part with you, ile take vp french Commodities, veluet kirtles, and taffery fore-parts; ile ha that I go for, or ile make halfe the hot-houses in Deepe smoake for this tricke.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: What are your bookes made euen with your accounts?

sp.speaker: 1 Pren.
sp.l: I haue compar'd our wares with our receipt,
And, sind sir, ten poundes difference.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Bones a me knaue,
Ten pounds in a morning: heer's the fruit
Of Dagger Pyes, and Alehouse-guslings:
Make euen your Reckonings, or Gods mother knaues,
You shall all smart for't.
Harke you fellow Goodman,
Who tooke the ten pound of the countrie Chapman.
That told my master the newe fashions?
Fore God not I.
Nor I.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Bones a me, knaues,
I haue pa'yd soundly for my Countrey newes:
What was his name?
Now afore God, I know not.
I neuer saw him in the shoppe till now.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Now bones a me, what carlesse Knaues keepe I,
Giue me the booke, what habite did he were?
As I remember me, a tawnie coate.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Art sure: then set him downe Iohn Tawnie-coate.
Ten pound in trust vnto Iohn Tawnie-coate.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Bones a God man, these knaues will begger me.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Birladie sir, ten pounds is too much to loose,
But ten times ten pound cannot shake your credite.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Thanke God for all: when I came first to towne,
It would haue shooke me shrewdly: but M. Gresham.
How stands your difference with Sir Thomas Ramsey?
Are you made friends yet?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: He is so obstinate,
That neither Iuries, nor Commissions,
Nor the intreaties of his neerest friends,
Can stoope him vnto composition.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Tis passing strange: were Hobson in your coate,
Ere i'de consume a pennie amongst Lawyers,
Ide giu't poore people, bones a me I wold.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: A good resolue: but sit Thomas Ramsies mind
Is of another temper, and ere Gresham
Will giue away a tittle of his right,
The Law shall begger me.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Bones a me, man, twill doe that quickly.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: To preuent which course,
The Lady Ramsey hath by earnest sute,
Procur'd the reuerent Preacher Doctour Nowell,
A man well reckoned for his graue respect.
To comprimise and ende our difference,
The place the Lombard, ten of clocke the houre
Appointed for the hearing of our cause.
Shall I request your friendly companie,

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: With all my heart, both companie and purse:
Bones a me, knaues, looke better to my shoppe:
Men of our trade must weare good husbands eyes,
Mongst many Chap-men there are fewe that buyes.
My leysure now your businesse attends,
Time's wonne not lost, that's spent to make men friends.
sp.stage: Enter Doctor Nowell, and my Lady Ramsie.

sp.speaker: Ladie.
sp.l: Good Master Doctor Nowell, let your loue
Now shew it selfe vnto me: such as they,
Men of the chiefest note within this Citie
To be at such a iarre, doth make mee blush
Whom it doth scarse concerne: you are a good man,
Take you the course in hand and make them friends,
Twill be a good dayes worke, if so it end.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: My Lady Ramsie, I haue heard ere this
Of their contentions, their long suite in Lawe,
How by good friends they haue beene perswaded both,
Yet both but deafe to fayre perswasion:
What good will my word doe with headstrong men?
Breath blowne against the winde, retures againe.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Although to Gentlemen and Cittizens,
They haue beene so rash, yet to so graue a man,
Of whom none speake but speake with reuerence,
Whose words are gather'd in by euery eare
As flowers receiue the dew that comfort them,
They will be more attentiue: pray take it in hand,
Tis a good deede, t'will with your vertue stand.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: To be a make-peace doth become me well,
The charitable motion good in you,
And in good sooth t'will make me wet mine eyes,
To see them euen, haue beene so long at ods.
And by my meanes, ile doe the best I can,
But God must blesse my words, for mans but man.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I thanke you heartily, and by the houre I know.
They will be presently heere on the Lumbard,
Whither I drew you for this intent:
And see, sir Thomas is come: pray breake with him.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: Good day to sir Thomas Ramsie.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: M. Deane of Powles, as much to you:
Tis strange to see you here in Lumberstreet,
This place of trafficke whereon Marchants meete.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: Tis not my custome: but sir Thomas.
sp.stage: Enter M. Gresham, and old Hobson. Hob. Come, come:
sp.l: Now body a me, I sweare not euery day,
You are too to much to blame: two Citizens,
Such as your selfe, and sir Thomas Ramsie are,
To beat your selues in Law sixe or seuen yeare,
Make Lawyers, Turneyes clarkes, and knaues, to spend
Your money in a brabling controuersie,
Euen like too fooles: see where the other is,
With our Deane of Powles, nere better met,
We two as Vmpiers will conclude a strife
Before the Clocke strike twelue, that now is aleuen:
Lawyers this full seuen yeare haue brabled in,
And with a cuppe or two of merry-godowne,
Make them shake hands: Is't not well said M. Deane?

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: And I could wish it as well done, M. Hobson.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Ile haue you both know though you are my friends,
I scorne my cause should stoope or yeele to him,
Although he be reputed Ramsie the rich.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: And Gresham shall perceiue that Ramsies purse,
Shall make him spend the wealth of Osterley,
But he shall know.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Know, what shall I know?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: That Ramsie is as good a man as Gresham.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: And Gresham is as good a man as Ramsie.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: Tut, tut, tut, Gresh Tut in thy teeth although thou art

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Bones a me, you are both to blame: (a Knight.
We two like friendes, come to conclude your strife,
And you like fish-wiues fall a scolding here.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: How stands the difference twixt you my good friends?

sp.speaker: Ladie.
sp.l: The impatience both of the one and other,
Will not permit to heare each other speake:
Ile tell the cause for both, and thus it is.
There is a Lordship called Osterley,
That M. Gresham hath both bought and built vpon.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: And t'is a goodly Manour, M. Deane.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Which Osterley before he dealt therein,
Sir Thomas my husband here did thinke to buy,
And had giuen earnest for it.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: Then Gresham here, deales with the Land-seller,
And buyes my bargaine most dishonestly.

sp.speaker: Gres.
sp.l: God for his mercie touch mine honesty,
Away with comprimize, with taking vp,
The Lawe shall try my cause and honestie.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: T'will proue no better then it should Gresham.

sp.speaker: Gres.
sp.l: T'will prooue as good as Ramsies, Ramsie.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: Do not I know thy rising?

sp.speaker: Gres.
sp.l: I, and I know thine.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: Why mine was honestly.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: And so was mine.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Hey day, bones a me
Was't euer seene two men to scold before?
Here's, I know thy rising, and I know thine,
When as Gods blessing, that hath rais'd them both.
Am I worse because in Edwards dayes,
When Poperie went downe, I did ingrosse
Most of the Beades that were within the Kingdome,
That when Queene Marie, had renewed that Church,
They that would pray on Beades were forc't to me:
I made them stretch their purse-strings, grew rich thereby,
Beads were to me a good commoditie.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: No matter for your beads, my right's my right.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: Yet Gresham shall well know he hath done me wrong.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Ther's law inough to right you, take your course.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: Reason being made mans guide, why is't that force
Are violent passions to sweepe the soule
Into such head-long mischiefes: tis onely this,
Reason would rule, Nature a Rebell is.
You know the fire of your contention,
Hath onely cherishing and is maintain'd
From vild affections, whose strength's but thus
As soultry heat doth make vs shunne the fire,
An extreame colde doth alter that desire:
All things that haue beginnings, haue their ends.
Your hate must haue conclusion, then be friends.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Friends, M. Doctor Nowell, looke you heere,
Heer's M. Greshams hand.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Ile bring the tother.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: This seuen yeare they haue beene in law together.
How much such men as they in seuen yeares spend,
Lawyres may laugh at, but let wise men iudge.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Friend Hobson.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: Wife Lady.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Bones a me, ile hold you fast,
I will not haue a couple of such men
Make cackling lawyers rich, and themselues fooles,
And for a trifling cause: as I am olde Hobson.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Sir Thomas Ramsis.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: Master Gresham.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Body of mee, both shall be school'd, M. D. Nowell,
You know the cause that this contention,
Is onely that he bought a peece of land
This had giuen earnest for, all Adams earth,
And Adams earth is free for Adams sonnes,
And tis a shame men should contend for it:
What ere you speake shall for a sentence stand,
And being spoke, they shall shake hand in hand.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: If I must then decide the difference,
Thus it shall bee: because that Sir Thomas Ramsis,
Had earnest giuen before you bought the Land,
Though you were not acquainted with so much,
I doe award he haue a hundred pound
Toward his charges, and for that you
Haue both payd for the Land, and built vpon it,
It shall continue yours: the money you haue spent,
Either account it lost, or badly lent.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Gods precious, I haue spent fiue hundred pound,

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: And so haue I.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: No matter.
The iudgement stands, onely this verdite too,
Had you before the law fore-seene the losse,
You had not now come home by weeping crosse.
Strifes may as well haue end twixt honest men,
Lawyers set fooles to Law, then laugh at them.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Fore God tis true: and now I thinke vpon it,
We might at first haue ended it by friendes,
And made our selues merry with the money:
But being done, tis done, then sir Thomas Ramsey,
Let's leaue both loosers, tis but a thousand pound,
And if you be as well content as I,
Here weele shake hands and let our anger dye.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Shake hands, by the Marie god, sir Thomas what else,

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: You shew your selues our friends, to make vs friends,
Then in good sooth ile not be obstinate.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Nay, M. Doctor Nowell ioyne their hands,
I know the reuerent regard of you
Hath tempred both their hearts.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Madame, tis true: I thinke to any but so good a man,
We should haue both beene headstrong: but come.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: With all my heart, long may you liue together,
As friend should be to friend, brother to brother.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Amen, amen, sir Thomas.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: Amen, amen, Master Gresham.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Amen, amen, to you both.
And is not tis better then euery Terme to trot after Lawyers?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Good sooth tis true, if we could thinke it so,
But tis mans nature, he desires his woe.
Now passion of me sir Thomas, a cruell storme,
And we stay long we shall be wet to the skinne,
I doe not lik't, nay and it angers mee
That such a famous Citie as this is,
Wherein so many gallant Marchants are,
Haue not a place to meete in, but in this,
Where euery shoure of raine must trouble them:
I cannot tell but if I liue: lets step into the Popes head,
We shall be dropping dry if stay here:
Ile haue a roofe built, and such a roofe,
That Marchants and their wiues, friend and their friends
Shall walke vnderneath it as now in Powles.
What day of the Month is this?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Day M. Gresham, let me see:
I tooke a fellowes word for twentie pound
The tenth of March, the tenth of March.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: The tenth of March, well if I liue,
Ile raise a worke shall make our Marchants say,
T'was a good showre that fell vpon that day. How now Iacke?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Sir, my M. here hauing preferd me to be his Factor into
I am come to take my leaue of you. (France

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: I thanke him for his care of thee: M. Hobson,
My kinsman's come to take his leaue of me,
He tels me you are sending him for France.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Bones a me knaue, art there yet?
I thought thou hadst been halfe way there by this.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: I did but stay sir, to take my leaue of my Vncle.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: O M. Hobson, he comes in a very good time,
I was bethinking me whom I might send
To fetch this hundred pound, I am set to pay
To sir Thomas Ramsey: nay, as we are friends
Weele haue all Couenants kept before we part.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: God graunt that I may see it.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Here Iohn take this seal'd Ring,
Bid Timothy presently send me a hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: I sit.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: I am sure he hath it ready told for thee,
Weele stay here on the Lumbard till thou comest.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: Nay stay good Iohn, thou knowst my dwelling Iohn?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: In Powles Church-yard Sir.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: The hundred pound thou art sent for, bring it thither

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Yes marry will I sir.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: And my good friends, since that so long a strife
Hath ende by my perswasion, ile entreat,
My house may entertaine you for this time.
Where with such necessaries weele passe the time,
As God shall best be pleased, and you contented:
I keepe no ryot, nor you looke for none,
Onely my table is for euery one.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: A cup of Sacke and welcome M. Deane,
Nature is best contented with a meane.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: As I told you Timothy,
You must send my Vncle straight a hundred pound:
A dines at Doctor Nowels, and gaue me in charge
To hast with the money after him.

sp.speaker: Thimo.
sp.p: You come to me Iohn for a hundred pound, I thanke my spirituall maker I haue the charge of many hundreds of his now Iohn: I hope Iohn you feare God. (too.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Feare God, S'foot what else, I feare God and the deuill

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.p: I must tell you Iohn and I know it, you haue not fed of the spirituall food, but edified by faith and suffered the tares of the wild affections to be burnt.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Foote thou wouldst not haue me make my selfe a French Martyr, to be burnt at these yeares wouldst thou?

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.p: I haue knowne them Iohn of our Church, haue beene burnt for other sinnes before thy yeares.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: I by my faith Timothy it may be you haue, for as close as you carry your teeth together, with indeed good brother, I doe not thinke but once in a yeare, a man might finde you quartered betwixt the Mouth at Bishops-gate, and the preaching place in Spittle.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Now you talke of the Spittle, I must say in very deede I haue beene in the Spittle.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: It is the more like Timothy you haue beene acquainted with the pox then.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: But if you should thinke Iohn, that I would be there to commit, deale, or to speake more prophanely, to venture in the way of all flesh, you doe wrong me being a brother of the faith.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Come right your selfe and your Master then, and send him this one hundred pound, here's his seal'd Ring, I hope a warrant sufficient.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Vpon so good securitie Iohn, ile fit me to deliuer it.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Spend it, God send mee but once to finger it, and if I doe not make a Flanders reckoning on't, and that is as I haue heard mad wags say, receiue it heare and reuell it away in an other place: let me bee spit out of the roome of good fellowship, and neuer haue so much fauour to touch the skirt of a Taffatie peticote.
sp.l: Tut I am yong, mine Vncle's an old chuffe,
And ile not want by God, since he hath enough.
I must not let this same wainscot-face, yea & nay, heare me tho.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Here Iohn, accept my dutie to my Master, I must tell you Iohn, I would not haue trusted you Iohn, without so susficient a discharge.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: I am the lesse beholding vnto you, but now I hau't, because you preach't to me vpon my demande of it, ile be so bold to lecture to you vpon your deliuerie, Timothie you know the Prouerbe good Timothy, That the still Sow eates all the draffe: and no question the most smooth tongu'd fellow, the more arrant knaue: God forbid I should call you so Timothy, yet I will leaue this for your further remembrance.

lg.l: Vnder the yea and nay, men often buy
Much cosonage, finde many a lye:
He that with yea and nay makes all his sayings,
Yet prooues a Iudas in his dealings,
Shall haue this written o're his graue,
Thy life seem'd pure, yet di'd a knaue.

sp.speaker: Timothy.
sp.p: Doe you heare Iohn, you know the Chapmans word in London, Ile trust you but no further then I see you, you haue the hundred pound Iohn, but for that you haue wrong'd vs that loue to be edified, I will goe with you to my Master, and see the money deliuered.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Why, a trusted me to come with't.

sp.speaker: Timothy.
sp.l: I care not by yea, and nay, ile goe by yea and nay, I will.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Let me but aske thee this question, Whither dost thou goe, in any loue to thy master, or to me?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Though my master be my master, yet you haue stur'd my stomack.

sp.speaker: Iohn:
sp.p: I thought there was the fruit of your Puritane patience, come let's along, and if I doe not shew your religion a trick shall be scarse disgested with pepins or cheese, let me bee cal'd Cut, Come along.
sp.stage: Enter Honestie the Sergeant, and Quick.

sp.speaker: Honestie.
sp.p: Fellow Quicke, pray thee haue a care if thou canst see Iohn the Vpholster, I must needes airest him.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: How much is the debt?

sp.speaker: Honestie.
sp.l: Some 50. li.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Dost thou thinke he is able to put in bayle to the action?

sp.speaker: Honestie.
sp.l: I thinke scarse ynough.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Why then wee'le arrest him to the popes-head, call for the best cheere in the house, first feede vpon him, and then if he wil not come off, carry him to the counter, but if he wil stretch some 4. or 5. li. being the sums so great he shal passe, weele make him sweare he shall not tell he was arrested, and weele sweare to the creditor we cannot meet with him.

sp.speaker: Honest.
sp.l: Fore God thou sayst well.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: I haue serued Sent the Perfumer, Tallow the Currier, Quarrell the Glasier, and some three or foure more of our poore smelts so this morning.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Hart I haue cour'st thorow two or three Lanes, yet the miching slaue followes me so close I can not giue him the slippe for this hundred pound: as God saue me now ti's in my hand i'do rather be hang'd then part from it: Foote, t'will make a man merry halfe a yere together in France, command wenches or any thing: part from it quoth you, that were a iest indeed: shall a yong man as I am, and though I say it indifferent proper, goe into a strange countrey, and not shew himselfe what mettell hee is made of when a comes there: I protest a very good hundred pound, a hundred pound will goe farre in France, and when a man hath it not of his owne, who should hee make bold withall for it, if he may not with his Vncle; but see if that thin fac't rogue be not come againe, I must haue a tricke for him.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: For all your fore-long too and fro, by yea and nay, ile follow you.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Will you, there should bee Sergeants here abouts, will you: Lord if it be thy will send mee to hit of one, and if I doe not shew you a tricke, thou shouldst be a Sergeant by thy peering so.

sp.speaker: Honest.
sp.l: Why M. Iohn so I am. (thy name?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Thou art happily met: I am looking for one, what's

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: My name M. Iohn, I haue beene merry at your Vncles many a time, my name's Honestie.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: I faith.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: Nay, ile assure you his name is Honestie, and I am Quick

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Honestie! who the pox gaue thee that name? (his Yeoman.
But thou must doe an office for my Vncle:
Heare Quicke, runne thou before and enter the action,
Ther's money, an action of an hundred pound
Against Timothy Thin-beard, M. Greshams Factor,
I hope I shall teach you to dog me.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: An action against Thin-beard, I goe.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Here Honestie, there's money for thy arrest,
Be sure to take good Bayle or clap him fast:
I hope I shall shew you a trick.

sp.speaker: Honest.
sp.l: Mum for that.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: See where he is, God prosper it.
Fasten vpon him like a hungry Dog vpon a peece of meate:
And if this be not a tricke to chaste a foole,
A more knaue learne me, and ile goe to schoole.

sp.speaker: Honest.
sp.l: I arrest you Sir.

sp.speaker: Tim:
sp.l: Arrest me, thou seruant to Sathan: at whose sute?

sp.speaker: Honest.
sp.l: At your Masters, M. Greshams.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: O God for thy mercie, M. Iohn, M. Iohn.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Nay, nay, this 100. li, hath other worke in hand for me,
You are in the Deuils hand, and so agree.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: My good friend, now what must become of me?

sp.speaker: Honest.
sp.p: Vnles, wee shall to the Tauerne, and drinke till you can send for Baile, you must to the Counter.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Is ther no difference made betwixt the faithfull and the vnfaithfull.

sp.speaker: Honest.
sp.p: Faith very little in paying of debts: but if you be so holy, I maruel how you run so farre behind hand With your M.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
I must confesse I owe my M. 500. li. How I came so, it is not fit to lay the sins of our flesh open to euery eie, & you know
the saying, Tis bad to do euill, but worse to boast of it: yet hee aboue knowes that sometimes as soone as I haue come from Bowe-church, I haue gone to a Baudie-house. (your knauerie.

sp.speaker: Honest.
sp.l: Nay it appeares so, that now your M. hath smelt out

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Not to commit in very deed good friend, but only to see fashions or to recreat & stir vp our drowsie appetites.

sp.speaker: Honest.
sp.p: Well here comes my fellow Quick, and vnles you wil content vs for staying, you must along to the Counter.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I hope you thinke The Labourer is worthie of his hire: we will stay here at the Tauerne, and Quick I will content thee, to carry a letter to my master, wherein I will make him a restitution of his 500. li. by repentance, and shew him the way that my fraile nature hath run into.

sp.speaker: Honest.
sp.l: Well, weele be pay'd by the houre.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: It will not be amisse if you buy an houre-glasse.
sp.stage: Enter D. Nowel, Gresham. sir Tho. Ramsie, Hobson, Lady Ramsie,

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Come M. D. Nowell, now we haue done
Our worst to your good cheere, wee'd faine be gone:
Onely we stay my kinsmans long returne,
To pay this hundred pound to sir Thomas Ramsie.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: Then assure you, he will be heare presently:
In the meane time, I haue drawne you to this walke,
A Gallerie, wherein I keepe the Pictures
Of many charitable Citizens:
That hauing fully satisfied your bodyes,
You may by them learne to refresh your soules.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Are all these Pictures of good Cittizens?

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: They are, and ile describe to you some of their births,
How they bestowd their liues, and did so liue
The fruits of this life might a better giue.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: You shall gaine more in shewing this to vs,
Then you haue showne.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Good M. Deane, I pray you shew it vs.
This was the Picture of sir Iohn Philpot sometimes Mayor,
This man at one time, at his owne charge,
Leauied ten thousand souldiers, guarded the Realme
From the incursions of our enemies:
And in the yeare a thousand three hundred and eightie,
When Thomas of Woodstocke, Thomas Percie with other noble
Were sent to ayd the Duke of Britannie, (men,
This sayd Iohn Filpot furnisht out foure ships
At his owne charges and did release the armor
That the poore souldiers had for victuals paw'nd.
This man did liue when Walworth was Lord Maior
That prouident, valiant, and learned Citizen,
That both attacht, and kild the traytor Tyler,
For which good seruice Walworth the Lord Maior,
This Filpot, and foure other Aldermen,
Were knighted in the field.
Thus did he liue, and yet before he di'd
Assur'd reliefe for thirteene poore for euer.

sp.speaker: Gres:
sp.l: By the marry God a worthy Citizen:
On good my Deare.

sp.speaker: Now:
sp.l: This sir Richard Whitington three times Maior,
Sonne to a Knight, and Prentise to a Mercer,
Began the Librarie of Gray-Friars in London;
And his Executors after him did build
Whittington Colledge, thirteene Almes-houses for poore men,
Repair'd S. Bartholmewes in Smithfield,
Glased the Guild-hall, and built Newgate.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Bones of mee then I haue heard lyes,
For I haue heard he was a scullion,
And rai'sd himselfe by venture of a Cat.

sp.speaker: Now:
sp.l: They did the more wrong to the gentleman.
This sir Iohn Allen Mercer and Maior of London,
A man so graue of life that he was made
A priuie Counsellor to King Henrie the eight,
He gaue this Citie a rich Coller of gold,
That by the Maior succeeding should be worne;
Of which sir William Laxton was the first,
And is continued euen vnto this yeare,
A number more there are, of whose good deeds
This Citie florisht.

sp.speaker: Gresh:
sp.l: And we may be ashamed,
For in their deeds we see our owne disgrace,
We that are Citizens are rich as they were.
Behold their charitie in euery streete,
Churches for prayer, Almes-houses for the poore,
Conduits which bring vs water: all which good
We doe see and are relieu'd withall,
And yet wee liue like beasts, spend time and die,
Leauing no good to be remembred by.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Among the Stories of these blessed men,
So many that inrich your Gallarie,
There are two womens Pictures: what were they?

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: They are two that haue deseru'd a memorie,
Worthy the note of our Posteritie:
This Agnes Foster, wife to sir A. Foster,
That fre'd a Beggar at the grate of Lud-gate,
Was after Maior of this most famous Citie,
And builded the South-side of Lud-gate vp,
Vpon which wall these Verses I haue read.

lg.l: Deuout soules that passe this way,
For M. Foster late Maior honestly pray,
And Agnes his Wife to God consecrate,
That of pitty this house made for Londoners in Lud.gate:
So that for lodging and water here nothing they pay,
As their Keepers shall answere at dreadfull Doomes day.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: O what a charitable deed was this!
This Aue Gibson who in her husbands life,
Being a Grocer, and a sherife of London,
Founded a free Schoole at Ratcliffe,
There to instruct three-score poore children,
Built fourteene Almes-houses for fourteene poore
Leauing for Tutors 50. li. a yeare,
And Quarterly for euery one a Noble.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Why should not I liue so, that being dead
My name might haue a register with theirs.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Why should not all of vs being wealthy men,
And by Gods blessing onely rais'd; but
Cast in our mindes how we might them exceed
In godly workes, helping of them that need.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Bones a me tis true: why should we liue,
To haue the poore to curse vs being dead?
Heauen grant that I may liue, that when I die,
Although my children laugh, the poore may cry.

sp.speaker: Now.
sp.l: If you will follow the religious path,
That these haue beat before you, you shall win heauen,
Euen in the mid-day walkes you shall not walke the street.
But widowes orisons, Laysars prayers, Orphans thankes,
Will flye into your eares, and with a ioyfull blush,
Make you thanke God that you haue done for them:
When otherwise theil fill you eares with curses,
Crying we feed on woe, you are our Nurses.
O ist not better that yong couples say,
You rais'd vs vp, then you were our decay:
And mothers tongues teach their first borne to sing,
Of your good deeds, then by the bad to wring.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: No more M. D. Nowell, no more,
I thinke these words should make a man of flint.
To mend his life: how say you M Gresham?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Fore-god they haue starred teares into my eyes,
And M. D. Nowel you shall see
The words that you haue spoke, haue wrought effect in me.

sp.speaker: Ladw.
sp.l: And from these women I will take a way,
To guide my life for a more blessed stay.

sp.speaker: Now.
sp.l: Begin then whilst you liue, least being dead,
The good you giue in charge be neuer done,
Make your owne hands your executors, your eyes ouer-seers,
And haue this saying euer in your mind:
Women be forgetfull, children be vnkind,
Executors be couetous, and take what they find.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: In my time I haue seene many of them.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Ile learne then to preuent them whilst I liue,
The good I meane to doe; these hands shall giue.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: The matter you wot of sit is done.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Done knaue, what's done?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Is in hucksters handling sir, and heare he commend him vnto you.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Mary God knaue dost tel me Riddles, what's all this?

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: A thing will speake his owne minde to you,
If you please but to open the lip.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Bee your leaue Gentlemen, I am come to smell out my master here: Your kins-man Iohn sir, your kins-man Iohn.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: O he has brought the hundred pound, where is he?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: It appeares by this, the matter is of lesse waight.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: What more paper:!
Fellow, what hast thou brought me here, a recantation?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: It may be so for he appeares in a white sheet.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: Indeed he seemes sorry for his bad life..

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Bad life, bad life knaue, what meanes all this?
M. D. Nowell, pray read it for me,
And Ile read that my kins-man Iohn hath sent:
Where is he knaue?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Your worship is no wiser then you should be, to keepe any of that cote.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Knaue thou mean'st.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Knaue I meane sir, but your kins-man Iohn,
That by this time's well forward on his way.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Hey-day, what haue we here, knauery as quick as Eeles?
Weele more of this.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: You were best let me helpe you hold it sir.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Why knaue, doost thinke I cannot hold a paper.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Helpe will do no hurt for if the knauery be as quicke as an Eele, it may chance to deceiue you.

lg.l: I am a Marchant made by chance,
And lacking coyne to venture:
Your hundred pound's gone toward France,
Your Factor in the Counter.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: No sir, he is yet but in the Tauerne at counter gate, but he shall soone be in if you please.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Away knaue, let me read on.

lg.l: My father gaue me a portion,
You keepe away my due:
I haue payd my selfe a part to spend,
Here's a discharge for you.

sp.l: Precious cole, here's a knaue round with me.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: Your Factor Timothy Thin beard writes to you,
Who as it seemes is arrested at your sute.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: How, at my sute!

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: And heare confesseth by vsing bad companie,
He is run behind hand fiue hundred pound.
And doth intreat you would be good to him.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: How, run behind hand fiue hundred pound,
And by bad companie: M. Deane of Powles,
He is a fellow seemes so pure of life,
I drust haue trusted him with all I had had.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: Here is so much vnder his owne hand.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Ha, let me see, who set you to arrest him?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: Why your kins-man Iohn sir, your kins-man Iohn.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: He, ha, infaith I smell the knauerie then:
This knaue belike mistrusting of my kinsman,
Would come along to see the money giuen me:
Mad Iacke hauing no tricke to put him off,
Arrests him with a Sergeant at my sute,
There went my hundred pound away: this Thin-beard then
Knowing himselfe to haue playd the knaue with me,
And thinking I had arrested him indeed,
Confesseth all his trickes with yea, and nay:
So her's fiue hundred pound come, one runne away.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Bones a me, M. Gresham, is my man Iohn
Gone away with your hundred pound?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Faith it appeares so by the acquittance that I brought.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: No matter M. Hobson, the charge you trust him with,
Ile see he shall discharge, I know he is wilde,
Yet I must tell you ile not see him suncke:
And afore-god it hath done my heart more good,
The knaue had wit to doe so mad a tricke,
Then if he had profited me twice so much.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: He euer had the name of mad Iacke Gresham.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Is the more like his Vncle, Sir Thomas Ramsie
When I was yong I doe remember well,
I was as very a knaue as he is now.
Sirra, bring Thin-beard hither to me, and sir Thomas Ramsie,
Your hundred pound ile see you pay'd my selfe:
Ha ha, mad Iack, Gramercie for this slight,
This hundred pounds makes me thy Vncle right.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p: I sure tis in this Lane, I turned on the right hand comming from the Stockes, nay, though there was master carles, man carels, and all careles, ile still be honest Iohn, and scorne to take any mans ware but ile pay them for it: I warrant they thinke me an arrant knaue, for going away and not paying, and in my conscience the master cudgeld the men, and the men the master, and all about me, when as God saue me I did it innocently. But sure this is the Lane, there's the Windmill, there's the Dogs head in the pot, and her's the Fryer whipping the Nuns arse: ti's here about sure.
sp.stage: Enter in the shop 2. of Hobsons folkes, and opening the shoppe.

sp.l: Come fellow Crack, haue you sorted vp those wares?
Mark't them with 54. they must be pack't vp.
I haue don't an houre agoe: haue you seal'd vp
My masters Letter to his Factor Iohn Gresham?
It is at Deepe in France to send him Matches,
For he must vse them at Bristow faire.
I, and the Poste receiued it two houres since.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p: Sure it is here about, the kennel was on my right hand, and I thinke in my conscience I shall neuer haue the grace of God and good lucke, if I doe not pay it: Gods foot, looke here, looke here, I know this is the shop by that same stretch-halter, O my masters, by your leaue good fellowes.

sp.l: You are welcome sir, you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p: Indeed that's the common saying about London, if men bring money with them.

sp.l: O sir, money customers to vs are best welcome.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p: You say well, so they should be. come turne o're your bookes, I am come to pay this same ten pound.
And we are ready to receiue money: what might we call your name?

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p: Why my name is Iohn Good-fellow, I hope I am not ashamed of my name.
Your Kin are the more beholding to you, fellow Cracke turne o're the Callender, and looke for Iohn Good-fellow.

sp.l: What comes it to?

sp.speaker: Tawnie.
sp.l: Tenne pound.
You will haue no more wares with you, will you sir.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p: Nay prethee not too fast, let's pay for the old before we talke of any new.
Iohn Good-fellow, fellow Nimble-chaps, here's no such name in all our booke.
I thinke thou art mop-ey'd this morning, giue me the booke, Letter I, Letter I, Letter I: when had you your ware?

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: I had it some ten dayes agoe.

sp.p: Your name's Iohn Good-fellow you say, Letter I, Letter I, Letter I: You doe not come to mocke vs, doe you. Letter I, Letter I, Letter I. By this hand if I thought you did, I would knocke you about the eares afore wee parted fellow Cracke, get mee a Cudgell ready; Letter I, Letter I, Letter I: Foote here's no such name in all our Booke. Doe you heare fellow are you drunke this morning, to make vs looke for moone-shine in the water?

sp.speaker: Taw:
sp.p: Fut, art not thou drunke this morning, canst not receiue the money that's due to thee? I tell thee I had ten pounds worth of ware here.
And I tell thee Iohn Goodfellow, here's no such name in our booke, nor no such ware deliuered.

sp.speaker: Taw:
sp.p: Gods precious, there's a iest indeed, so a man may bee sworn out of himself, had not I ten pounds worth of ware here?

sp.l: No Goodman goose, that you had not.

sp.speaker: Taw:
sp.p: Hyday, here's excellent fellowes, are able to make their maisters hornes grow through his head in a month, they cannot only carelesly deliuer away his ware, but also they will not take money for it when it comes.
Doe you heare Hoyden, and my master were not in the next roome, Ide knocke you about eares for playing the knaue with vs, ere you parted.

sp.speaker: Taw:
sp.p: By the masse I thinke your master had more need knock you about the eares, for playing the Iackes with him, ther's your ten pounds, tell it out with a wanion, and take it for your pains.
Fut, here's a mad slaue indeed will giue vs ten pound in spight of our teethes.
Fellow Nimble Chaps, alas let the poore fellow alone, it appear's he is besides himselfe.

sp.speaker: Taw:
sp.p: By the masse, I thinke you will sooner make your master starke mad, if you play thus with euerie bodie.

sp.speaker: Hobs:
sp.l: Hyday, bones a mee, here's lazy knaues.
Past eight a clocke, and neither ware sorted,
Not shop swept.

sp.speaker: Taw:
sp.p: Good morrow to you sir, haue you any more stomacke to receiue money, than your men haue this morning?

sp.speaker: Hob:
sp.p: Money is welcome chaffer, welcome good friend, Welcome good friend.

sp.speaker: Taw:
sp.l: Here's mounsieur malapart your man, scorns to receiue it.

sp.speaker: Hob:
sp.l: How knaues, thinke scorne to receiue my money?
Bones a mee growne proud, proud knaues, proud.

sp.p: I hope we know sir you doe not vse to bring vp your seruants to receiue money vnlesse it be due vnto you.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: No bones a me knaues, not for a million:
Friend, come to pay me money, for what, for what,
For what come you to pay me money?

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: Why Sir, for ware I had some moneth agoe,
Being Pins, Points, and Laces,
Poting stickes for yong wiues, for yong wenches glasses,
Ware of all sorts which I bore at my backe
To sel where I come, with what do you lack, what do you lack?
What doe you lacke?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Bones a me a merry knaue: what's thy name?

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: My name sir is Iohn Good-fellow,
An honest poore Pedler of Kent.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: And had ten pound in ware of me, a moneth agoe:
Bones giue me the bookes, Iohn Good-fellow of Kent.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: O sir, Nomine & naturae, by name and nature,
I am as well knowne for a good-fellow in Kent,
As your Cittie Summer's known for a knaue,
Come sir will you be telling.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Tel me of no tellings, bones of me here's no such matters
Away knaue away, thou owest me none, out of my doores.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p: How, owe you none say you! this is but a tricke to try my honestie now.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: There's a groat, goe drinke a pint of Sacke,
Comfort thy selfe thou art not well in thy wits;
God forbid, pay me ten pound not due to me.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p: Gods dickins here's a iest indeed, master mad, men mad, and all mad, here's a mad houshold: doe you heare M. Hobson, I doe not greatly care to take your groat, and I care as little to spend it, yet you shall know I am Iohn, honest Iohn, and I will not be out fac't of my honesty, here I had ten pounds worth of ware, and I w'll pay for it.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Nimble-chaps, call for help Nimble-chaps,
Bones of me the man begins to raue.
Master I haue found out one Iohn Tawnie-cote,
Had ten pounds worth of ware a moneth agoe.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: Why that's I, that's I: I was Iohn Tawnie-cote then,
Though I am Iohn Gray-cote now.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Iohn Tawnie-cote! welcome Iohn Tawnie-cote.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: Foot doe you thinke ile be out fac't of my honestie?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: A stoole for Iohn Tawnie-cote, sit good Iohn Tawnie-cote.
Honest Iohn Tawnie-cote, welcome Iohn Tawnie-cote.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: Nay, ile assure you we are honest all the generation of vs,
There t'is to a Doyt I warrant it, you need not tell it after mee,
Foot doe you think ile be out fac't of mine honestie?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Thou art honest Iohn, honest Iohn Tawnie-cote:
Hauing so honestly pay'd for this,
Sort vp his packe straight worth twentie pound,
Ile trust thee honest Iohn, Hobson will trust thee:
And any time, the ware that thou doost lacke,
Money or money not, ile stuffe thy packe.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: I thanke you Master Hobson, and this is the fruit of honestie.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: Be your leaue M. Hobson, I bring this fauour to you,
My royall Mistresse Queeno Elizabeth,
Hath sent to borrow a hundred pound of you.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: How, bones a mee, Queene know Hobson, Queene know
And send but for one hundred pound: Friend come in; (Hobson?
Come in friend, shall haue two, Queene shall haue two:
If Queene know Hobson, once her Hobsons purse,
Must be free for her she is Englands Nurse:
Come in good friend, ha, Queene know Hobson,
Nay come in Iohn wee'le dine together too.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: Make vp my packe and ile along from you
Singing merrily on the way,
Poynts, Poynts, Gloues, and Purses,
Pokingsticks, and blacke Iet-rings,
Cambricks, lawnes, and pretie things:
Come maydes and buy my backe doth croke,
I haue all that you want: what doe you lacke?
What doe you lacke?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Our Citties Sword-bearer and my very good friend,
What haue our honourable Court of Aldermen
Determin'd yet shall Gresham haue a place,
To erect this worthy building to his name,
May make the Cittie speake of him for euer.

sp.speaker: Sword.
sp.l: They are in earnest counsell sir about it.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Be you my Agent too and fro to them,
I know your place and will be thankfull to you:
Tell them I waite here in the Maiors Court,
Beneath in the Sheriffes Court my workemen waite
In number full a hundred, my Frame is ready,
All onely stay their pleasure, then out of hand
Vp goes my worke, a credite to the Land.

sp.speaker: Sword.
sp.l: I shall be dutifull in your request.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Doe good M. Sword-bearer, now when this worke is
It shall be in the pleasure of my life, (rais'd,
To come and meet our Marchants at their houre,
And see them in the greatest storme that is
Walke dry, and in a worke I rais'd for them:
Or fetch a turne within my vpper walke,
Within which square I haue ordered Shoppes shall bee
Of neat but necessariest Trades in London.
And in the richest sort being garnish't out,
T'will doe me good to see shops with faire wiues
Sit to attend the profit of their husbands:
Yong maides brought up young men as prentises.
Some shall prooue masters and speake in Greshams praise,
In Greshams worke we did our fortunes raise.
For I dare say both Countrey and the Court,
For wares shall be beholding to this worke.
sp.stage: Enter Sword-bearer, Lord Mayor, and Sheriffes.

sp.speaker: Sword.
sp.l: M. Gresaam,
Thus sends the Lord Mayor and Court of Aldermen.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: Or rather come to bring the newes our selfe:
We haue determin'd of a place for you
In Corne-hill, the delightfull of this Cittie,
Where you shall raise your Frame: the Cittie at their Charge
Hath bought the houses and the ground, (pound;
And payd for both three thousand fiue hundred three & twentie
Order is giuen the houses shall be sold,
To any man will buy them and remooue them,

sp.speaker: Shirife.
sp.l: Which is already done, being fourescore housholds,
Were sold for 478. pound.
The plot is also plain'd at the Citties charges,
And wee in name of the whole Cittizens,
Doe come to giue you full possession
Of this our purchase, whereon to build a Burse,
A place for-Marchants to assemble in,
At your owne charges.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: M Sherife Ile doo't, and what I spend therein,
I scorne to lose day, neglect is a sinne:
Where be my worke men?

sp.speaker: Work.
sp.l: Here, here with trowell and tooles ready at hand.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Come fellowes, come:
We haue a Frame made, and we haue roome
To raise it: but M. D. Nowell, and M. Hobson,
We haue your presence in a happie time,
This seuenth of Iune we the first stone will lay
Of our new Burse, giue vs some Brickes:
Here's a bricke, here's a faire Soueraigne,
Thus I begin, bee it hereafter told
I laid the first stone with a peece of gold.
Hee that loues Gresham follow him in this,
The gold we lay, due to the workemen is.

sp.speaker: Worke.
sp.l: O God blesse M. Gresham, God blesse M. Gresham.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: The Mayor of London M. Gresham followes you:
Vnto your first this second I doe fit,
And lay this peece of gold a toppe of it.

sp.speaker: Shri.
sp.l: So doe the Sheriffes of London after you.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: And bones of me, old Hobson will be one,
Here's fellowys there's my gold giue me a stone.

sp.speaker: Work.
sp.l: God forbid a man of your credite should want stones

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: Is this the Plot sir of your worke in hand?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: The whole Plot both of forme and fashion.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: In sooth it will be a good edifice,
Much Art appeares in it: in all my time
I haue not seene a worke of this neat forme:
What is this vaultage for, is fashioned here?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Stowage for Marchants ware and strangers goods,
As either by exchange or otherwayes are vendable.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: Here is a middle round and a farre space,
The round is greater, and the space
Seemes open: your conceite for that?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: The grates giue light vnto the Cellerage,
Vpon the which ile haue my friends to walke,
When heauen giues comfortable raine vnto the earth:
For that I will haue couered,

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: So it appears.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: This space that hides not heauen from vs,
Shall be so still, my reason is,
Ther's Summers heat, as well as winters colde,
And I allow and here's my reason for't,
Tis better to be bleak't by winters breath,
Then to be stifled vp with Summers heat:
In cold weather walke drie and thicke together,
And euery honest man warme one another:
In Summer then when too much heat offends,
Take aire a Gods name Marchants or my friends.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: And what of this part that is ouer head?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: M. Deane in this:
There is more ware there then in all the rest,
Here like a parish for good Cittizens
And their faire wiues to dwell in, ile haue shoppes
Where euery day they shall become themselues
In neat attire, that when our Courtiers
Shall come in traines to pace old Greshams Burse,
They shall haue such a girdle of chaste eyes,
And such a globe of beautie round about:
Ladies shall blush to turne their vizards off,
And Courtiers sweare they ly'd when they did scoffe.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: Kind M. Gresham this same worke of yours,
Will be a Tombe for you after your death,
A benefit to Tradesmen and a place
Where Marchants meet their trafficke to maintaine,
Where neithèr could shall hurt them, heat, nor raine.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: O M Nowell I did not forget
The troublesome storme we had in Lumbar-fleet,
That time Sir Thomas and I were aduersaries,
And you and M. Hobson made vs friends.
I then did say, and now ile keepe my word,
I saw a want and I would helpe afford:
Nor is my promise giuen you when you shew'd
That rancke of charitable men to vs,
That I would follow their good actions
Forgot with me, but that before I die,
The world shall see Ile leaue like memorie.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Fore-God my Lord, haue you beheld the like!
Looke how it streakes, what doe you thinke of it?

sp.speaker: Shir.
sp.l: Tis a strange Comet M. Hobson,
My time to my remembrance hath not seene
A sight so wonderfull. M. D. Nowell,
To iudge of these things your experience
Exceedeth ours, what doe you hold of it?
For I haue heard that Meteors in the ayre,
Of lesser forme, lesse wonderfull then these,
Rather fore-tell of danger's imminent,
Then flatter vs wish future happinesse.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: Art may discourse of these things none can iudge
Directly of the will of heauen in this,
And by discourse thus far I hold of it.
That this strange starre appearing in the North,
And in the constellation of Cassiopey,
Which with three fixed starres commixt to it,
Doth make a Figure Geometrycall,
Lozengewise cal'd of the learned Rombus,
Conducted with the hourely Moone of heauen,
And neuer altred from the fixed sphere,
Fore-tels such alteration that my friends,
Heauen grant with this first sight our sorrow ends.

sp.speaker: Hob:
sp.l: God, will be done M. Deane, hape what hap will,
Death doth not feare the good man but the ill.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Well said M Hobson.
Lets haue a day, that if death come to morrow
Hee's rather messenger of ioy then sorrow.
Now sir what newes from Barbarie?

sp.speaker: Fact.
sp.l: Vnwelcome newes sir, the King of Barbarie is slaine.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Ha, slaine by treason or by warre.

sp.speaker: Fact.
sp.l: By warre, in that renowned Battell,
Swift Fame desires to carry through the world:
The Battle of Alcasar, wherein two Kings
Besides this King of Barbarie was slaine,
Kings of Moroco and of Portugale,
With Stewkeley that renowned Englishman
That had a spirit equall with a King,
Mad fellow with these Kings in war-like strife,
Honor'd his Countrey and concluded life.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Could newes birladie, the venture Gentlemen
Of threescore thousand pound with that dead King,
Lies in a hazard to be wonne or lost:
In what estate consists the Kingdome now?

sp.speaker: Fact.
sp.l: In peace, and the succeeding happie,
Was crown'd then King when I tooke ship from thence.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: To that King then be Messenger from vs,
And by the sound of Trumpet summon him?
Say that thy Master and a London Marchant,
Craues due performance of such couenants
Confirm'd by the late King vnto our selfe,
That for the summe of three-score thousand pound,
The trafficke of his Sugars should be mine.
If he refuse the former bargaine made,
Then freely claime our money that we lent:
Say that our coyne did sted the former King,
If he be Kind we haue as much for him.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: By the Marie-god it was a dangerous day,
Three Kings beside yong Stewkeley slaine:
Ile tell you my Lord Maior what I haue seene
When sword and bucklers were in question,
I haue seene that Stewkeley beat a street before him,
He was so familliar growne in euery mouth,
That if it happened any fighting were,
The question straight was, was not Stewkely there.
Bones a me he would hew it. Now, what newes with you?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Here is a Letter sent you from Iohn Gresham.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: O an answer of a Letter that I sent,
To send mee Matches against Bristow faire,
If then any were come.

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: I cannot tell Sir well what to call it, but in steed of matches of ware, when you reade your Letter, I beleeue you will find your Factor hath matcht you.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: What's here, what's here.
sp.p: As neare as I could gesse at your meaning, I haue laboured to furnish you, and haue sent you 2. thousand pounds worth of Match.
How, bones knaue, 2. thousand pounds worth of Match!

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Faith M. neuer chafe at it, for if you cannot put it away for Match, it may be the hang-man will by some of it for halters.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Bones a me, I sent for matches of ware, fellowes of ware.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: And Match being a kinde of ware, I thinke your Factor hath match't you.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: The blasing Starre did not appeare for nothing:
I sent to be sorted with matches of ware,
And he hath sent me nought, but a commoditie of Match,
And in a time when ther's no vent for it.
What doe you thinke on't Gentlemen,
I little thought Iack would haue seru'd me so.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Nay M. Hebson grieue not at Iack's crosse,
My doubt is more and that I laugh at lesse.

sp.speaker: 1. Lord.
sp.l: You haue trauel'd sir, how do you like this building?
Trust me it is the goodliest thing that I haue seene,
England affords none such.

sp.speaker: 2. Lord.
sp.l: Nor Christendome:
I might say all the world has not his fellow.
I haue been in Turkies great Constantinople,
The Marchants there meet in a goodly temple,
But haue no common Burse in Rom, but Rome's
Built after the manner of Franckeford, and Eniden:
There where the greatest Marts and meeting places
Of marchants are haue streets and pent-houses,
And as I might compare them to themselues,
Like Lumber-street before this Buisse was built.

sp.speaker: 1. Lord.
sp.l: I haue seene the like in Bristow.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: Good morrow to your honours.

sp.speaker: 2. Lord.
sp.l: Thankes to my good Lord Major.
We are gazing here of M. Greshams worke.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: I thinke you haue not seene a goodlier Frame.

sp.speaker: 2. Lord.
sp.l: Not in my life, yet I haue been in Uenice,
In the Realto there called S. Markes,
T'is but a bable if compar'd to this.
The nearest that which most resembles this,
Is the great Burse in Anwerpe, yet not comparable
Either in height or widnesse: the faire Sellerage,
Or goodly shoppes aboue: O my Lord Major,
This Gresham hath much grac't your Cittie London,
His fame will long out-liue him.

sp.speaker: 1. Lord.
sp.l: It is reported you sir Thomas Ramsie are as rich as he.
This should incite you to such noble workes,
To eternize you.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: Your Lorship pleases to be pleasant with me,
I am the meanest of a many men
In this faire Cittie, M Greshams fame
Drawes me as a spectator amongst others,
To see his cost, but not compare with it,

sp.speaker: 1. Lord.
sp.l: And it is cost indeed.

sp.speaker: 2. Lord.
sp.l: But when to fit these emptie roomes about here,
The pictures grauen of all the English Kings
Shall be set ouer and in order plac'st,
How glorious will it then be?

sp.speaker: 1. Lord.
sp.l: Admirable!

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: These very Pictures will surmount my wealth.

sp.speaker: 1. Lord.
sp.l: But how will M. Gresham name this place?

sp.speaker: 2. Lord.
sp.l: I heard my L. of Lecester to the Queene
Highly commend this worke, and she then promis'd
To come in person and heare christen it,
It cannot haue a better God-mother:
This Gresham is a royall Cittizen.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: He feasts this day the Russian Ambassadour,
I am a bidden Guest:
Where if it please you.

sp.speaker: 1. Lord.
sp.l: Good sir Thomas,
We know what you would say, We are his Guests
Inuited two: yet in our way we tooke
This wonder worth our paynes, it is our way
To Bishop-gate to M. Greshams house,
Thether so please you wee'l associate you.
sp.stage: Enter Gresham leading in the Ambassadour, Musick, and a Banquet serued in: the Ambassadour set: Enter Sir Tho. Ramsie, the 2. Lords, my Lady Ramsie the Weights in Sergeants gowns with one Interpreter.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Lords all at once welcome, welcome at once,
You come to my new buildings vp sitting,
It hath beene long in labour now deliuer.
anon weele haue a health to it.
This Russian Prince the Emberours Ambassadour
Dooth not our Language vnderstand: Interpreter,
Say that the wee bidde him wel-come.

sp.speaker: Inter.
sp.l: The Prince speakes Latine,
And in that language weele interpret for him:
Salutem tibi optat & adicentum tuum grauissume iste Londinensis.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Istum libens audio, ages illi meo nomine Ex animo gratias, funde quod bibamus.

sp.speaker: Inter.
sp.l: He gladly thankes you for his royall wel-come
And drinkes to you.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: We vnderstand that signe.
Come let our full crown'd cups o'reflow with wine,
Wel-come againe faire Lords.

sp.speaker: 2. Lord.
sp.l: Thankes M. Gresham.
We haue beene viewing of your workes.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: My Burse how doe you like it Lord,
It is a pretie bable.

sp.speaker: 2. Lo.
sp.l: Tis a faire worke.
Her Maiestie intends to name the place.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: She doth her seruant Gresham too much grace,
It will be pretie when my Pictures come
To fill those emptie roomes, if that holdes,
That ships rich is worth her waight in gold.

sp.speaker: 1. Lo.
sp.l: It will be rare and famous.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: What was it that the Russian whispered?

sp.speaker: Inter.
sp.l: He aske me what interpreter the Queene
Would in his Embasse imploy.

sp.speaker: Giesh.
sp.l: None, tell him none.
For though a woman, she is a rare Linguist,
Where other Princes vse Interpreters,
She propria voce, I haue some Latin too:
She of her selfe heares all their Embassies,
And herselfe answers them without Interpreter,
Both Spanish, Latin, French, and Greeke,
Dutch, and Italian, so let him know:
My Lord of Lecester sent me word last night,
And I am prouder on't then on my building,
The Queene to grace me and my workes the more,
The seuerall Ambassadors then will heare,
And them in person answere.

sp.speaker: 2. Lord.
sp.l: T'is most true.
sp.stage: Enter a Gentleman wispering to sir Thomas Ramsie.

sp.speaker: Gresham.
sp.l: The Russian with the Frence.
What would that Gentleman sir Thomas?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: He is a Marchant and a Jeweller:
Mongst other stones he saith he hath a Pearle
Orient and round, waighing so many carets
That it can scarse be valewed: the French king,
And many other Dukes haue for the riches
And prize refus'd to buy it: now he comes,
To offer it to this Ambassadour.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Shew him the Pearle Interpreter:
The Lord Ambassadour.

sp.speaker: Inter.
sp.l: Mercator quidem & aurifex spectandum, tibi profere
Gēmam domine serenissime.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Et pulchra & principe digna, interroga quanti iudicat?

sp.speaker: Inter.
sp.l: He commends it to be both rich and faire,
And desires to know how you vallew it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My prise sir, is fifteene hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Quantivalet?

sp.speaker: Inter.
sp.l: Mille quin gentis minis,

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Non, non nimis peceara est ista Gemma.

sp.speaker: Inter.
sp.l: He saith it is too deare, he will not buy it.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: I will peruse your pearle, is that your prise?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I cannot bate one crowne and gaine by it.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Wee'l not be accessarie to your Losse,
And yet consider all things some may thinke vs
To be but bare of treasure at this time,
Hauing disburst so much about our workes:
Yet if our ships and Trade in Barbarie
Hold currant we are well: what newes from Sea,
How stands my ships?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Your ships in which all the Kings pictures were,
From Brute vnto our Queene Elizabeth:
Drawne in white marble, by a storme at sea
Is wrack't and lost.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: The Losse, I way not this:
Onely it greeues me that my famous building,
Shall want so rich and faire an ornament.

sp.speaker: L. Ram.
sp.l: It touches all the Cittie; for those pictures
Had doubly grac't this royall edifice.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: Me thinkes the ships losse most should trouble you.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: My ships but wealth, why we haue wealth;
The pictures were the grace of my new Burse,
So I might them in their true forme behold,
I car'd not to haue lost their waights in gold.

sp.speaker: 1. Lord.
sp.l: A noble Citizen.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Our Factor, what good newes from Barbarie?
What sayes the King, speake, didst thou sommon him?
Or hast thou brought my threescore thousand pound?
Or shall I haue the Sugars at that rate?
If so, new marble Pictures weele haue wrought,
And in a new ship from beyond-sea brought.

sp.speaker: Fact.
sp.l: The King that in the regall chaire succeedes
The King late dead I summon'd, and demaunded
Either your money tendred, or the Sugars
After the rate propos'd, hee denied both
Alleaging though he was successiue heire,
He was not therefore either tide to pay
The late Kings debts, nor yet to stand vnto
Vnnecessarie bargaines: notwithstanding
To gratifie your loue, the King hath sent you
As presents, not as satisfaction:
A costly dagger, and a paire of slippers,
And there's all for you three-score thousand pound.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Birlady a deare bargaine.

sp.speaker: 1. Lord.
sp.l: I feare me this will plague him, a strange crosse,
How will he take this newes, losse vpon losse.

sp.speaker: 2. Lord.
sp.p: Nay, will it not vndoe him, doth he not wish his buildings in his purse.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: A dagger that's well,
A payre of slippers come vnto my shooes,
What 30. thousand pound in sterling money,
And payd me all in slippes, then Hoboyes play,
On slippers ile daunce all my care away:
Fit, fit, he had the iust length of my foot.
You may report Lords when you come to Court,
You Gresham saw a paire of slippers weare
Cost thirtie thousand pound.

sp.speaker: 1, Lo.
sp.l: Somewhat too deare.
Nor yet for all this treasure we haue lost,
Repents it vs one penny of our cost.

sp.speaker: 2. Lo.
sp.l: As royall in his vertues as his buildings.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: These losses would haue kild me.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Ieweller,
Let's see thy pearle: goe pound it in a Morter,
Beate it to powder then returne it me,
What Dukes, and Lordes, and these Ambassadours
Haue euen before our face refusd to purchase
As of too high a price to venture on,
Gresham a London Marchant here will buy.
What is it broken small? fill vs some wine,
Fuller, yet fuller till the brim or'e-flows,
Here 16000. pound at one clap goes,
In stead of Sugar, Gresham drinkes this pearle
Vnto his Queene and Mistresse: pledge it Lords,
Who euer saw a Marchant brauelier fraught,
In dearer slippers or a richer draught?

sp.speaker: L. Ram.
sp.l: You are an honour to all English Merchants
As bountifull as rich, as Charitable
As rich as renowned as any of all.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: I doe not this as prodigall of my wealth,
Rather to shew how I esteeme that losse
Which cannot be regain'd, A London Marchant
Thus tread on a kings present: Ieweller,
My Factor shall deliuer you your money.
And Lords so please you but to see my Schoole,
Of the seuen learned liberall Sciences,
Which I haue founded here neere Byshops-gate,
I will conduct you. I will make it Lords
An Vniuersitie within it selfe,
And giu't from my reuenewes maintenance.
W'are not like those that are not liberall
Till they be dying, what wee meane to giue,
Wee wil bestow, and see done whilst we liue.
Attendance, come, th'ambassadour, guesse all,
Your welcom's great, albeit your cheer's but small

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: Hard world, when men dig liuing out of stones,
As wretched miserable I am inforc't:
And yet there liues more pittie in the earth,
Then in the flint-bosomes of her children,
For shee's content to haue her aged brest
Mangled with matrocks, rent and torne with spades,
To giue her children and their children bread,
When man more flinty then her stonie Ribbes
That was their mother, neither by intreates,
Teares, nor complaints will yeeld them sustinance,
But tis our ages fault the mightier,
Teare liuing out of vs, we out of her.
sp.stage: Enter Hobson in his gowne and slippers.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Mother a me what a thick myst is here:
I walked abrod to take the mornings ayre,
