And I am out of knowledge, bones a me
What Meads, what Inclosures haue we here?
How now old Hobson, doat in thine old age?
A foole a threescore, whether wilt thou wit?
I crost the water in my gowne and slippers,
To see my rents and buildings of the Bancke-side,
And I am slipt cleane out of ken, fore-god
A wooll-gathering.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: Either mine eare's deceiued,
Or I should know that tongue: tis so indeed,
Each word he speakes makes my torne heart to bleed.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Ha, ha, I smile at my owne foolerie,
Now I remember mine old Granmother
Would talke of Fayries and Hobgoblins,
That would lead milke-maides ouer hedge and ditch,
Make them milke their M. neighbours kine,
And ten to one this Robin Godfellow,
Hath led mee vp and downe the mad mans maze.
I heare some companie, for shame all whist,
Sit thee downe Hobson a right man, in the mist.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: Tis he alas, when the rough hand of want
Hath cast vs downe, it loades vs with mishaps:
I broke my day with him, O had that fatall houre
Broken me heart: and Villaine that I was,
Neuer so much as write in my excuse,
And he for that default hath sew'd my bill.
And with an execution is come downe
To seaze my houshold stuffe, imprison me,
And turne my wife and children out of dores.
What shall I flie him? no hee's pitifull:
Then with my teares I will importune him:
God saue you M. Hobson.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Hobson, Bones a mee,
What voyce is that? art thou a man, or friend?
Tell me if thou beest that Will of the wispe,
That leadst me this wild Morice: I coniure thee
To leaue mee to my selfe.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: O M. Hobson,
As euer you haue beene a poore mans friend,
Continue still so, Insult not or'e thy fortunes,

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: I am in the mist, what art thou, speake?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: A Debter of your worships.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: A Debter of mine, mother of me thou lyest,
I know thee not, nor doe I know this place:
If thou owest me any thing, pay mee with thy loue,
And if thou beest acquainted in these woods,
Conduct me to some Towne, or direct roade
That leads to London, and ile here discharge thee
Of debts and duties, and beside impart
Somewhat to cherish thee.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: What should I thinke?
He knowes mee, and for feare I should escape him,
Hee would entice me to the Officers.
O Master Hobson tho not for mine owne,
Yet for my wife and my poore childrens sakes,
If your intent bee to imprison mee,
Vpon my knees I doe intreat you spare mee:
The goods you trusted mee withall, I haue not wasted
In royot and excesse, but my kind heart,
Seeing my helpelesse neighbours in distresse,
By reason of the long and extreame dearth,
Some I relieued, some trusted with my goods,
Whose pouerties not able to repay.
Then beare with me a little, your rich store
Hath sau'd my life and fed a hundreth more.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Now bones a mee another Tawniecote:
What's thy name Knaue?

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: Iohn Rouland sir,

sp.speaker: Hobson.
sp.l: Bones a mee!
I thought as much: art not thou Tawnicote?

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: I am the man whom you cal'd Tawniecote.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: And I the Hobson that will pitie thee:
Now bones a mee, what makest thou with a spade?

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: This spade alas, tis all the wealth I haue,
When my poore wife and children cry for bread,
They still must cry till these haue purchas'd it:
They must goe naked till these hardened hands,
When the cold breth of Winter strikes on them,
Till these haue earn'd it.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Now alas good soule,
It melts my heart to heare him, and mine eyes
Could weepe for companie, what earn'st a day?

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: Little God knowes:
Though I be stirring earelier then the Larke,
And at my labour later then the Lambe,
Towards my wife and childrens maintenance,
I scarsely earne me three-pence by the day.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Alas the while, poore soule I pittie them,
And in thy words as in a looking-glasse,
I see the toyle and trauell of the countrey,
And quiet gaine of citties blessednesse.
Heauens will for all, and should not we respect it
We were vnworthy life: but bones of me,
Dost thou thinke to pay me twentie pound,
And keepe thy charge, earning a groat a day?

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: God blesse my labours, I hope I shall,
I haue this quarter by exceeding thrift,
Bare clothing, and spare diet scrap't together
Fiue shillings in a purse which I lay vp,
Towards your worships debt.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Giue it me, somewhat hath some sauour,
And yet shal I spend that which the poore laborer got?
No God forbid, old Hobson nere will eate,
Rather then surfet vpon poore mens sweat:
Take it againe, and by thy children bread.
But soft the mist doth breake, what towne is this?

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: Dedford and it like your worship.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Bones a me, to Detford came I to doe charitie:
I see t'was Gods appointment,
But who comes here, bones a me honest Tim,
T'was said in London you were bound for France,
And I determined to haue write by you.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: By yea and nay, M. Hobson tis no vntruth, I was bound for France, landed in France, dispatch't some secret businesse for a sister in France, and from her haue french tokens to deliuer to the sister hood, whom I shall first incounter in England.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Bones a me Tim, so speedy in your iourney,
It seemes your businesse was of much import.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Verely it was, and it stood chiefly betweene two women: & as you know women loue to haue their busines dipatch't.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Mother a me Tim, I am glad of it,
But how doo's my factor Iohn Gresham in France?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
You grauely may better consider of that then I can discourse, but withall I pray you thinke hee is a wilde youth: there are Tauernes in France, yet I doe not thinke Iohn Gresham is giuen to frequent them, & yet I must remember you, he is a youth, and youth may be drawne to expences, England's on this side France, on it, the Sea betwixt him and his Master, but I doe
not thinke him guiltie, yet I could say.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Mother of me, leaue of these Parables,
And tell me plainely, is hee not a wencher?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: By yea, and by nay sir without Parable, I am no tel-tale, I haue seene him in company with Madona such a one, or such a one, it becomes not flesh and blood to reueale: your worship knowes he is in France, the Sea betwixt him and you, and what a yong youth in that case is proone vnto: your grauitie is wise, Ile not say so much as I saw him drinking with a French Lady, or Lasse in a Tauerne, because your grauitie is wise, but if I had, it had beene lesse then perhaps you imagine on such a wilde youth, as he no question doos deserue.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Mother of mee tis so, In a French Tauerne
Kissing the Ladie, and the Sea betwixt vs:
I am for you M. Iohn: thus in my gowne and slippers,
And night-cap and gowne ile steppe ouer to France,
Here Tawnicote, receiue thou my seal'd ring,
Beare it to my Factor, bid him by that token
Sort thee out fortie pounds worth of such wares
As thou shalt think most beneficiall:
Thou art a free-man, vp with thy Trade agen,
Ile raise thee Rouland, if God say Amen.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: I know not how.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Tut bones a mee man peace,
Hobson will doo't; Tou owest me but twentie pound,
Ile venture fortie more, Timothy here shall be thy witnesse
To my Factor in this businesse.
To all our friends in London say, I am gone
Ouer to France, I am for your M. Iohn.

sp.speaker: Courtez.
sp.l: Sweet youth thou art too yong, and yet scarse ripe
To taste the sweetnesse of my mellowed loue.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: That's the reason I set thy teeth an edge thus, but thou knowst I promis'd to haue about with thee at our last parlay, and I am come to performe my word, name the weapon.

sp.speaker: Curtez.
sp.l: Nothing but kisses, and enticing lookes,

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Then ward your lips well, or youle ha the first venney.
I haue no warde but this; my tender Sex
Haue not the manly skill to breake a thrust:
Oh how I dote on thee! I haue tride ere now
The sweatie Spaniard, and the carowsing Dane,
The foggy Dutch-man, and the fiery French,
The briske Italian, and indeede what not:
And yet of all and all, the Englishman
Shall goe for me: I yo'are the truest Louers,
The ab est, last night, and the truest men
That breath beneath the Sunne.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Why then the Englishman for thy money, God a mercy little rogue, there's no loue lost ile assure thee. I am my Masters Factor, and thou hast a Commoditie that I must needs take vp, and not en er't into his Cash-booke neither. Little thinkes my master in England, what ware I deale withall here in France: but since tis offer'd me at the best hand, ile venter on't though I be a looser by the bargaine.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I would be priuate, least the tell-tale ayre
Whisper our loue. I prethe let vs in,
To the inner chamber, I am iealous
Of all eyes but mine owne to looke vpon thee,
I would haue none to see thee but my selfe:
In amorous armes to fold thee but my selfe:
To associate, talke, discourse or dally with thee:
Clip, graspe hands, or kisse thee but my selfe.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Who would not be a Marchant venturer, and lay out for such a faire returne; I shall venture the doubling of my years presently: I thinke I haue met with a better Commoditie then Matches, and my Master cannot say but hee hath met with his match: this tis to haue the Land & the Sea betwixt me & my maste, here can I keepe my french Reuels, and none say so much as blake is mine eye, preche litle pinckany bestow this Iewell a me.

sp.speaker: Curtez.
sp.l: This Iewel's a Loue: aske my life tis thine:
But this an English factor whom you know
Gaue me at his departure out of Rhoane,
And I haue vow'd to keepe it for his sake,
Any thing but this Iewell.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
But if I could get his Iewell cleanly, and carry it him
ouer at my returne for a token, t'were a iest worth laughing at: but and thou wilt not giue me this Iewell, prethe giue mee this same chaine to were for thy sake.

sp.speaker: Curtez.
sp.l: This was another Countrey-mans of yours,
He made me sweare to kep't till his returne:
Aske me aught else, tis thine.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Why then this Ring.

sp.speaker: Curtez
sp.l: That you of all the fauours that I weare
Could finde out nothing but this ring? This ring,
A toy not worth the giuing: yet I sooner
Would part with life then this, a dying friend
Bequeath'd it at his death: But honey Loue
What shouldst thou talke of giuing, tis a word
Worne out of vse, it sounds not well in French:
A man should still say take, take to his Wench.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Then I say take, take this and this, still take heed of me least I shew you a slipperie tricke for this, tis the kindest wench in Christendome, but sheele part with nothing:
sp.l: Shall we haue another woing Roome?

sp.speaker: Curtez.
sp.l: What Rome thou pleasest, deare heart I agree,
Where ere I goe, there shall be roome for thee.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Any then, I may chance to make you wish rather my roome then, my companie and you looke not the better too't.
sp.stage: They with-draw: Enter at the other ende of the Stage, Hobson in his Gowne and slippers.

sp.speaker: Hobson.
sp.l: I haue slipt or'e into France, and in my slippers
Giuen all my friends the slippe, to see this Gallant
My man, he that hath matcht me: bones a me,
The knaue's a Prophet, else it could not be.
Hee's not at his Lodging; yet by an English Factor,
A fellow knowes not me, I was directed
Vnto this house, Ile know what busines
The knaue hath here. Pulsat.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: Whos's there? whos's at the doore? (man?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Damsell good day, is there not a fellow here an English-man Here's? an English-man, but none of your fellow neither: I hope sir we are not all fellowes at foote-ball.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Nay bones a me Girle, there's no reason we should he fellowes, but prethe my wench is there not one Iack Gresha here?

sp.speaker: Wench
sp.p: No goodman looke like a Goose, but ther's one M. Iohn Gresham an English Gentleman here: and you know no maners, you would be caught some.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Bones a me goodman Master, Master seruant,
Old goodman Hobson keeps Gentlemen to his men
Iacke turn'd to M. Iohn, mary sir reuerence,
The french maid taught me manners: well I hope
We shall haue a sight of the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: As you vse your selfe you may, and you may not.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Thou seest this Iewell well becomes mine eare,
This Ring my finger, and this chaine myne arme.

sp.speaker: Curtez.
sp.l: Ile be thy Iewell at thy lippes ile hang,
And as this Ring thy finger compasseth,
So shall these armes thy waste: these are but toyes,
Let me displace them.

sp.speaker: Wench:
sp.l: M. John here's a fellow below would speake with you.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: With me, what is he?

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: A simple Coxecombe, ile call him vp to you.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Doe my sweet Buffamacke: some Carryer or base knaue that hangs of my liberalitie: I hope tis not pure Tim, come for the second part of my beneuolence:
sp.l: Admit him in that he may praise our fate,
And see vs in our choisest pompe and state.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: Here's the fellow I told you of sir.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Zoones my Master.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Sante amen: Man Iohn, a wenchart Knaue, racke and manger knaue: bones a me, cannot a snatch and away serue your turne, but you must lie at racke and manger? Is this the ware you deale with seruant Iohn?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Chap-mans ware sir.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Sirra, Sirra, the dealing with such warre belongs not to our Trade: bones a me knaue, a Prentise must not occupie for himselfe but for his Master, to any purpose.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: And hee cannot occupie for his Master without the consent of his Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Come y'are a knaue.

sp.speaker: Ioh:
sp.l: Of your owne bringing vp sir.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: Besides, thou canst not keepe open shop here, because thou art a forrainer, by the lawes of the Realme.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: Not within the libertie: but I hope the suburbs tollerates any man or woman to occupie for themselues, they may doo't in the Citie too, and they be naturaliz'd once.

sp.speaker: Hobs:
sp.p: I but sirra, Ile haue none of my English Prentises Frenchefied; bones a me knaue, Ile haue thee deale with no such broken Commodities.

sp.speaker: Ioh:
sp.p: Your Worship must haue such as the Countrey yeelds, or none at all. But I pray ye sir, what's our trade?

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.l: What sayst thou knaue?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: That your worship is a Haberdasher of all wares.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.l: Bones of me, a Haberdasher of small wares.

sp.speaker: Ioh:
sp.p: And that the worst trade in all Christendome, and especially for French women: If they know a man to be a Haberdasher of small ware, thee'le haue no dealing with him, and therefore and you will haue any good Commodities here, you must change your copie, you neuer were a traueller: and therefore you know not what belongs too't; but you doe cleane mistake this Gentlewoman, and you take her for a light wench, weigh her in equall ballance, and you shall find her no such woman, no such woman Ile assure you.

sp.speaker: Hobs:
sp.l: No, what is she then Iohn?

sp.speaker: Ioh:
sp.p: Fore God sir, I would not haue you wrong the Gentlewomans repute, for a world. This Metressa deales for herselfe and hath many sorts of ware at commaund, I was now bargaining with her about a certaine Countrey Commoditie, and had not your comming mar'd the Match, one had gone through for't. And further should you wrong the Ladies reputation heere in Fraunce, Ile assure you they haue the law of their sides, but to confirme your good opinion of her, this is she of whom I tooke vp your Commoditie of Matches; be sorry for your offence, and excuse you to her for shame maister.

sp.speaker: Hobs:
sp.l: Bones a me knaue I cannot speake a word of French.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Nor she of English, but als one; vpon her Master, and what you cannot doe in words, perfourme in dumbe signes:
What in your slippers come to take me napping!
Ile giue you what you come for instantly,
And on the sudden make you so agast,
You will be glad to pardon what is past.

sp.speaker: Hobs:
sp.l: Madam, I crie you mercie for this wrong
Done to your Ladyship, I did suspect you
For a bad liuer, but I see you cleare,
For which mistake, I doe remaine your seruant.

sp.speaker: Courtez:
sp.l: Gramercie Mounsier.

sp.speaker: Hobs:
sp.p: How, would you my gray Mare see? If it like your Ladyship, I came by water, and neither of Mares backe, nor horse backe.

sp.speaker: Courtez:
sp.l: No, no point parla Francoi.

sp.speaker: Hobs:
sp.p: No indeed Ladie, my name is not Frauncis, your seruant and Iohn Hobson.

sp.speaker: Courtez:
sp.l: No point?

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: No points; yes indeed Ladie, I haue points at my hose, though I goe vntrust.

sp.speaker: Courtez:
sp.l: No point parla.

sp.speaker: Hobs:
sp.p: I haue no points in my parlour indeede, but I haue a hundred pounds worth in my shop.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Tush feare not lads, for he knowes none of you,
Doe but buffe out a little broken French,
And hee'le neuer take you to be Englishmen.

sp.speaker: Omnes Fact.
sp.l: We'le second the tother, but mannage it.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Be patient I beseech you Gentlemen,
Though you be officers, appointed here
To search suspected places, as this is
A most notorious filthy bawdie house,
And carrie all old rustie Fornicators
Aboue the age of fiftie vnto prison,
Yet know, this is an honest Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.l: A search, and this a bawdie house! why Iohn,
Bones a me knaue, How comes this to passe?

sp.speaker: 1. Fact.
sp.l: Measar man a moy.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p:
How, must you haue money of me? Ile know wherefore
first, by your leaues.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Nay Master I would it were but a money matter,
A Cage, or whipping-post, or so, tis worse:
What an old man to chide his Prentise hence,
As if he had some priuat businesse,
And then himselfe get close vnto his wench;
Nay whippping's all too good, had you found me so,
There had been worke ynough, there had been newes
For England, and a whole twelue months chiding
Of my good vncle.

sp.speaker: 2. Fact:
sp.l: Ie vow stre sau Amise.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.l: How, must I goe to prison for doing amisse?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: To prison? nay to whipping, I am sorrie,
And to my power I will intreat for you: Fie Master, fie.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.l: Bones a me Iohn, is not this a Ladie?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: No by my troth Master, such as in the Garden-allies, Ioane's as good as this French Ladie.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.l: Is not this Gentlewoman a dealer?
And hath she not a good commoditie?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Yes by my faith sir, I confesse both.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.l: Hath she not ware?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: She hath, and at a reasonable reckoning.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.l: And may not then a chapman deale with her?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Marry may ye sir, and Ile send news to your wife of your
The cause of your comming to France shalbe knowne, (dealing:
And what second hand commodities you tooke vp
Since your comming, my mistresse in England shall know
What vtterance you haue for your small wares in Fraunce:
Pen and inke, Ile set it downe in blacke and white,

sp.speaker: Hobs
sp.l: Bones a me Iohn, what Iohn? why honest Iohn?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: Harty commendations— vnderstand— reuerend master Hobson found with a whore in Roane,— place, a common bawdie house,— must be whipt.

sp.speaker: Hobs
sp.l: No more good Iohn.

sp.speaker: Ioh
sp.l: You haue had none yet,— whipt about the towne.

sp.speaker: Hobs:
sp.l: Swee honest Iohn, why bones a me knaue Iohn.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p:
In witnes wherof, all these honest gentlemen ey-witnesses, haue set to their hands, nay my mistresse shall know't, that's flat:
are there not Wenches ynow in England, but you must walke ouer sea in your slippers, and venture (being not shod) to come into Fraunce a wenching, what an old man too! she shall know what a slipperie tricke you would haue serued her in your slippers in Fraunce.

sp.speaker: Hobs:
sp.l: Nay, bones a me Iohn, friends, sweet Iohn all friends;
I doe confesse tha'st o'reacht thy master.
Ca me, ca thee, conceale this from my wife,
And Ile keepe all thy knauerie from thine vncle.

sp.speaker: Ioh:
sp.l: Well sir, In hope of amendment, I am content, and yet

sp.speaker: Hobs:
sp.l: Nay, bones a me, Ile take you at your word,
Besides I hope these honest Gentlemen
Will saue my credite.

sp.speaker: Ioh:
sp.l: Ile entreat for you.

sp.speaker: Hobs:
sp.l: Tis Logicke to me sir, I vnderstand you not.

sp.speaker: Ioh:
sp.p: Marry sir they say, if you will walke with them to their lodgings, for my sake they inuite you to dinner.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: God a mercie Gentlemen, God a mercie Iohn, but bones a me knaue, where are their lodgings?

sp.speaker: Ioh:
sp.l: Hard by, for why doe you aske?

sp.speaker: Hobs:
sp.l: I hope they'le bring me to no more bawdie houses,
I would not be taken napping againe for two and one:
But Gentlemen Ile accept of curtesie, and then Iohn
You shall with me to England, weele shew Fraunce
Our backs. And you will needs deale for your selfe,
Afore your time, you shall doo't in England.
Will you walke Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Curtes:
sp.l: Adue Mounsier, and Gresham farewell too,
No more of French loue, no more french losse shall doe.
sp.stage: Enter sir Thomas Ramsey being Maior, Sheriffe, Sword-bearer. &c.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho:
sp.l: Well sayd my Masters, see all things be readie,
To giue her Maiestie such entertaine
As may grace London, and become the state
Her highnesse brings along,
Wher's the Queene now?
She comes along the Strand from Sommerset house,
Through Temple-barre, downe fleet-street, and the cheape,
The North side of the Burse to Bishops gate,
And dines at master Greshams, and appoints
To returne on the South side through Corne-hill,
And there when she hath viewd the roomes aboue,
And walkes below, she'le giue name to the Burse.

sp.speaker: Sheriffe.
sp.l: The streets are fit, and all the Companies
Plac't in their liueries gainst her returne.
But my Lord Maior, shall these ambassadors
This day haue audience?

sp.speaker: Sir Thom:
sp.l: Admittance if not audience was graunted,
See therefore Trumpets, and all kinds of Musicke
Be plac'ct against her royall interuiew,
The steps with Arras spread where she ascends,
Besides giue charge vnto the shop-keepers
To make their best shewes in the vpper roomes,
Because the Queene intends to compasse it.

sp.speaker: Sheriff.
sp.l: Tis done my Lord.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho:
sp.l: The Queen hath din'd, the Trumpets sound already,
And giue note of her comming, bid the Waites
And Hoboyes to be readie at an instant.
sp.stage: Enter at one dore the Queene, Lecester, Sussex, Lords, Gresham; at the other Cassemer, the French and Florentine Ambassadours, Sir Tho: Ramsey, &c.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Lester and Sussex, are those the Ambassadors?

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: They are dread Soueraigne, he that formost stands,
The Emperours, the second is the French,
The last is the Florentine.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: We will receiue them.
sp.stage: Here the Queene entertaines the Ambassadors, and in their seuerall languages confers with them.
sp.l: Sussex and Lester place the ambassadours,
We at our Court of Greenwich will dilate
Further of these designes, where's Gresham?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Your humble subiect and seruant.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Our leasure now serues to suruey your Burse,
A goodly frame, a rare proportion.
This Cittie our great Chamber cannot shew vs
To adde vnto our same, a monument
Of greater beautie: Lecester what sayst thou?

sp.speaker: Lecest.
sp.l: That I my Soueraigne haue not seen the like.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Sussex nor you?

sp.speaker: Suss.
sp.l: Madam not I: This Greshams worke of stone,
Will liue to him when I am dead and gone.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: God blesse thy Grace Queene Besse.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Friend, what are you?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Knowest thou not mee Queene? then thou knowest no
Bones a me Queen, I am Hobson, and old Hobson (body:
By the Stockes, I am sure you know me.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: What is he Lecester, doost thou know this fellow?
Gresham or you?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: May it please your Maiestie,
He is a rich substantiall Citizen.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Bones a me woman send to borrow money
Of one you doe not know, there's a new tricke:
Your Grace sent to me by a Purseuant,
And by a priuie Seale to lend your Highnesse
An hundred pound: I hearing that my Queene
Had need of money, and thinking you had knowne me,
Would needes vpon the bearer, force two hundred:
The Queene should haue had three rather then faile,
I by this hand Queene Besse, I am olde Hobson
A Haberdasher, and dwelling by the Stockes:
When thou seest money with thy Grace is scant,
For twice fiue hundred pound thou shalt not want.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Vpon my bond.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: No, no my Soueraigne,
Ile take thine owne word without skrip or scrowle.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Thankes honest Hobson, as I am true mayde,
Ile see my selfe the money backe repayd:
Thou without grudging lendest, thy Purse is free,
Honest as plaine.

sp.speaker: Suss.
sp.l: A true well meaning man I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Gresh:
sp.l: Your Maiestie promist to giue the name
To my new Burse.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Gresham we will. A Herauld and a Trumpet.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: A Herauld and a Trumpet.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Proclaime through euerie high street of this citie,
This place to be no longer cal'd a Burse,
But since the building's stately, faire and strange,
Be it for euer cal'd, the Royall Exchange.
And whil'st this voice flyes through the citie forth-right,
Arise Sir Thomas Gresham now a Knight.
Be our Ambassadors conducted all
Vnto their seuerall lodgings: this 23. of Ianuarie
A thousand, fiue hundred, and seuentie, Elizabeth
Christens this famous worke: now to our Court
Of Greenwich; Gresham, thankes for our good cheere:
We to our people, they to vs are deere.

sp.speaker: La: Ram:
sp.l: What thinke you of my Husband master Deane,

sp.speaker: Now:
sp.l: As of all men, we are mortall, made of clay,
Now healthfull, now crasie; now sicke, now well;
Now liue, now dead, and then to heauen, or hell.

sp.speaker: La. Ram:
sp.l: It cheer's my heart, now in his deepe of sicknesse,
He is so charitable, and so well adicted
Vnto the poore's reliefe.

sp.speaker: Now:
sp.l: It ioyes me too:
Great is the number of the rich in shew
About the Citie, but of the charitable,
There are but few.

sp.speaker: La. Ram.
sp.l: Amongst these, I hold old Hobson well deserues
To be ranckt equall with the bountiful'st:
He hath rais'd many falling, but especially
One master Rowland, one cal'd Tawnicote:
But now an able Citizen late chosen
A Maister of the Hospitall.

sp.speaker: Now.
sp.l: I know him well,
A good sufficient man, and since he purchast
His Freedome in the Citie God hath blest
His trauaile with increase.

sp.speaker: La: Ram:
sp.l: I haue knowne old Hobson,
Sit with his neighbour Gunter a good man,
In Christs Church morne by morne, to watch poore couples
That come there to be married, and to be
Their common fathers, and giue them in the Church,
And some few Angels for a dower to boot,
Besides they two are cal'd the common Gossops
To witnesse at the Funt for poore mens Children,
Nor they refuse that on their helpe doe call,
And to speake truth, they're bountifull to all.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.l: Good morrow Master Doctor; my good Ladie!
Bones a me woman, thou look'st sad to day,
Thou hast not drunke a cup of sacke this morning.

sp.speaker: La: Ram.
sp.l: We haue been dealing of our charitie
This morning, to poore souldiers such as want.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.l: Gods blessing of your heart, need must be fed,
Let vs that haue it giue the hungrie bread.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: Where's master Hobson?

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.l: My new elected master of the Hospitall,
What hasty newes with you?

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: Oh sir, the loue I beare you makes me charie
Of your good name, your credit's deere to me;
You neuer were condemn'd for any thing,
Since I had first acquaintance with your name;
As now you are, you haue done a deed this day,
That hath from you tane all good thoughts away.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.l: Where? bones a me why? speake, why?

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: This day, you haue pursu'd the law seuerely
Against one Timothy, that stole from you
A hundred pound, and hee's condemn'd for it,
And this day he must die.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.l: Bones man, tis not so.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: He is by this, halfe way to Tyburne gone;
The suit was followed in Iohn Greshams name,
How can you then avow you know it not?

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.l: A horse, a horse, cart-horse, mault horse, anything
To saue the knaues life, I protest, I sweare
This was the first time that I heard the knaue
Hath beene in any trouble, bones of mee,
T'was done without my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: Yong Gresham in his name pursude his life.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: They are knaues both, a Horse,
A hundred thousand pound cannot make a man:
A hundred shall not hang one by my meanes:
Men are more worth then monie M. Rouland,
Come helpe me to a horse, the next I meete,
To saue the knaue's life galloppes through the street.

sp.speaker: Now.
sp.l: Men are more worth then money, a say's true:
Tis said by many but mantain'd by few.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: He is plaine and honest, how many great professors
Liue in this populous Cittie, that make shew
Of greater zeale, yet will not pay so deare
For a transgressors life: but few are found,
To saue a man would loose a hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Now.
sp.l: So suddenly return'd?

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: He rid to fast for me he hath been at buffets
With a poore Collier, and vpon his horse,
Is without saddle, bridle, bootes or spurres,
Gallop't toward S. Gyles.

sp.speaker: Now.
sp.l: They will take him for a mad man.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: Als one to him he doo's not stand on brauery
So he may doe men good, good deeds excell:
And though but homely done, may be done well:

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Heauen prosper his intent: now M. Doctor,
And M. Rouland, let me craue your companies,
To see my crazy husband, who hath made you
One of his executors, and would vse your paines
In these extreames of sickenesse.

sp.speaker: Now.
sp.l: I am pleas'd
Ile giue him phisicke for a soule diseas'd.
You are an early riser, my good Lord,
The blood of Youth that trafficks in the court
Must not be sluggish, your kind remembrance: (the trayne
My very good Lord, wee that are stars that waight vpon
Of such a Cynthia vnder which we liue
Must not be Tarde.
You haue said true, we are starters in one houre,
And our attendance is to waight one such a Queene,
Whose vertue all the world: but to leaue that
Which euery tongue is glad to commune with,
Since Monsiers first arriuall in the land,
The time that he was here, and the time since,
What royaltie hath beene in Englands Court,
Both princely reuelling, and war-like sport.
Such sports doe fitly fit our Nation,
That forraine eyes beholding what we are,
May rather seeke our peace, then wish our watre.
Heauen blesse our Soue raigne from her foes intent,
The peace we haue; is by her gouernment.
M. Doctor Parry.
Good Morrow M. Doctor.
You are an early riser sir.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.l: My Lord, my Lord, my very good Lord.
This Summer morning makes vs couetous
To take the profit of the pleasant ayre.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Tis healthfull to be stirring in a Morning.
It hath pleasde the Queene to shew him many fauours.
You say but right, and since his last disgrace,
The cause so great it had surely touch't his life,
Had not the Queene beene gracious: he seemes at Court
A man more gratious in our Soueraignes eye
Then greater subiects.
She hath giuen him much preferment,
In greatest place grac't him with conference:
Ask't for him in his absence, and indeed
Made knowne to vs he is one in her regard.
But did you neuer here the cause of his disgrace?
He did intend the murther of a Gentleman,
One M. Hares here of the Inner Temple,
And so far brought his purpose to effecte,
That M. Hare being priuate in his Chamber,
Hee watching as he thought fit time, broke in vpon him:
But he assaulted so, behau'd himselfe,
That he did guard himselfe, and attach't him.
From whence he was committed vnto New-gate,
And at the Sessions by twelue honest men,
Found guilty of Burglarie and condemn'd to die:
And had di'd, had her Grace not pardon'd him.
Shee is a gracious Princesse vnto all,
Many shee raiseth, wisheth none should fall.
Fie M. Doctor,
Your face beares not the habite it was wont,
And your discourse is altered, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: And if my brow be sad or my face pale,
They doe belie my heart, for I am merry.
Men beeing as you are, so great in grace
With such a royall Princesse, haue no reason.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Roome Gentlemen for my L. high Steward.
sp.stage: Enter the Earle of Lecester, all the Lords flocke after him, & exeunt.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: The discontend desire to be alone,
My wishes are made vp, for they are gone.
Here are no blabs but this, and this one clocke
Ile keepe from going with a double locke:
Yet it will strike, this day it must be done.
What must be done? what must this engine doe?
A deed of treason hath prepar'd mee too.
These too, these too, why they had life by her,
And shall these two kill their deliuerer?
The life that makes me rise? these once my sinne
Had forfeited, her mercie pardon'd me:
I had beene eaten vp with wormes ere this,
Had not her mercie giuen a life to this:
And yet these hands if I performe my oth,
Must kill that life, that gaue a life to both.
I haue tane the Sacrament to doo't, confe'rd
With Cardinal Cemo about it, and receiu'd
Full absolution from his Holynes,
Beene satisfied by many holy fathers,
During my trauels both in France and Italie,
The deed is iust and meritorious,
And yet I am troubled when I doe remember
The excellencie of her Maiestie,
And I would faine desist, but that I know
How many vowes of mine are gone to heauen,
My letters and my promises on earth,
To holy fathers and graue Catholikes:
That I would doo't for good of Catholicks.
Then in the Garden where this day shee walkes,
Her graces I will cast behind mine eyes,
And by a subiects hand, a Soueraigne dyes.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Cleare the way Gentlemen for the Queene:
Master Doctor Parry.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: O, let me see a difference in this man!
Before this Queene (that I am come to kill)
Shew'd me the gracious eye of her respect,
And gaue me countenance mong'st greatest Earles:
This man was forwarder to thrust me forth,
Then now he is humble to accept me in.
If then her Grace hath honour'd me so much,
How can this hand giue her a treacherous touch?
The Trumpets speake, heauen what shall I doe?
Euen what hell, & my dam'd heart shal thrust me too.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Faire day my Lords, you are all Larkes this morning,
Vp with the Sunne, you are stirring earely.

sp.speaker: Lecest.
sp.l: We are all subiects to your Soueraignes light.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: That you call dutie we accept as loue,
And we doe thanke you, nay we thanke you all;
Tis not to one, but tis in generall.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: The Queene would walke apart, forbeare my Lords.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Now, what makes me shake?
Doe Angels guard her, or doth heauen partake
Her refuge?

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: In such a Garden may a Soueraigne,
Be taught her louing subiects to maintaine;
Each Plant vnto his nature and his worth,
Hauing full cherishing, it springeth foorth.
Weedes must bee weeded out, yet weeded so,
Till they doe hurt, let them a Gods name grow.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Now Queene.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Who's there, my kind friend M. Doctor Parry?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: My must dread Soueraigne.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Why doe you tremble M. Doctor? haue you any sute to vs?
Shake not at vs, we doe our Subiects loue,
Or doos thy face shew signes of discontent
Through any heauie want oppresseth thee?
Though at our Court of Greene-wich thou wert crost
In suing to be Master of Saint Katherines,
To doe thee good seeke out a better place,
Shee'le giue thee that, the which hath giuen thee grace.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: I know your loue dread Queene: Now.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: M. Doctor, about the talke we had together,
Of English Fugitiues that seeke my life:
You told mee of them I am beholding to you.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: I did no more then dutie: O happie time!

sp.speaker: Queen:
sp.l: And will they still persist? doe they desire my blood?
That wake when I should sleepe to doe them good.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: O my maker! Parry, Villaine, Traitour,
What doost thou with that Dagge?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Pardon dread Soueraigne.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Pardon thou villaine, shewes thou art a Traitour,
Treason my Lords, Treason.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: Ha, by the ble'st place of heauen, treason & we so neere?
A Traitour with a Dagge, Gods holy mother.
Lords guard the Queene: are you not frighted Madam?
Ile play the Sergeant to arrest the wretch.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Be not so rash good Lecester, hee's dead already,
Strucke with remorce of that he was come to doe:
Pray let me speake with him? Say M. Doctor,
Wherein haue I deseru'd an ill of you,
Vnlesse it were an ill in pardoning you.
What haue I done toward you to seeke my life,
Vnlesse it were in taking you to grace.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Mercie dread Queene.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I thanke my God, I haue mercie to remit
A greater sinne, if you repent for it.

sp.speaker: Lecest.
sp.l: My Lords what do you meane, take hence that villain,
Let her alone, sheele pardon him againe:
Good Queene we know you are too mercifull,
To deale with Traitours of this monstrous kinde.
Away with him to the tower, then to death,
A Tratours death, shall such a Traitour haue,
That seekes his Soueraignes life that did him saue.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Good Lecester.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: Good Queene you must be rul'd.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Nay sfoote Iacke, hold on thy resolution: they say, that may happen in one houre that happens not againe in 7. yeare, and I should chance to take her in the right vaine, and she kindly bestow her selfe vpon me, why then there's a man made from nothing, for before God I haue spent all and am not worth any thing, and indeed vnlesse this same good old Ladie Ramsie take some pitie vpon me & take me for better for worse, God knowes in which of the two Counters I shall keepe my next Christmas in, but by this hand if shee will accept of mee in this miserable estate that I am in now, for before God, I haue neither money nor credite, as I am an honest man, and thats more I am fear'd, then any man will beleeue of mee, ile forsweare all women but her, & wil not kisse any of my neighbours wiues for a kingdome. heres the house, Ile knock at the doore: what shal I doo't in the Cauellere humour, with whos's within there Ho, or in the Puritane humour, with by your leaue good brother: faith in neither, for in the one I shall be taken for a swaggring knaue, and in the other to be an hypocriticall foole: but honest Iacke in thine own honest humour plaine dealing's a Iewel, and I haue vs'd it so long I am next doore to a begger.
But Gods precious, what a plague make these here? these 2. are two of my Creditors, I must stoppe their mouthes, fleet them from hence, or all the fats in the fire.

sp.l: M. Gresham, you are well met.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: I hope Gentlemen you will say so anon. But you are alone, are you not?

sp.l: Alone M. Gresham, why doe you aske?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: A man hath reason to aske, beeing as I am, that neuer seeth his Creditors, but is a feard of the Catch-pole. But you are kind my friends, and I thanke you, you will beare with me.

sp.l: I but M. Gresham, a man may beare till his backe breake.

sp.speaker: Iohn:
sp.p: I, Porters may; but you, that are sustantiall honest Cittizens, there is no feare to be made of your breaking, you know there's no man so low but God can raise him; and though I am now out at heeles, or so as you thinke, I am in the way of preferment, & hope to be able to pay euery man within this houre.

sp.l: We should be glad to see it.
But how pray Sir?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: How? why very easily, if I can compasse it: The truth is, though you would litle thinke it, I am a sutor for my L. Ramsey.

sp.l: But I dare sware she is no suter to you.
sp.stage: Enter Lady Ramsie, and D. Nowel.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Why that's true too; for if shee were a Suter to mee, we should be man and wife straight & you should haue your money within this halfe houre. But looke, looke where shee comes: as you are good-men mum, patience and pray for my proceedings: If I do speed as I am partly perswaded, you shall haue your own with the aduantage, if I should be crost you know the worst, forbearance is no acquitance: but mum, if it prooue a match & any of you should chance to be in the Counter, you know my marriage being spred, my word wil be currant, then mum.

sp.speaker: Now.
sp.l: Madam you are welcome into Lumber-street.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I thanke your curtesie, good M. Deane.

sp.speaker: Ioh:
sp.p: See how fortunately all things chance, if it happen as I hope it wil, she taking a liking to me, here is a Priest to marry vs presently Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady:
sp.l: Would you any busines with me sir?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Faith Lady necessary busines, & not to go far about the bush, I am come to be a Suter vnto you, & you know the fashion of yong men when they come a woing to ancient widowes, the way to speed is to begin thus.

sp.speaker: La:
sp.l: You are very forward sir.

sp.speaker: Ioh:
sp.p:
You would say so Lady if you knew how forward I would be: but Madam you are rich, and by my Troth I am very poore, and I haue been as a man should say starke naught: but hee goes
farre that neuer turnes, and if now I haue a desire to mend & being in so good a way, you know how vncharitable it were in you to put mee out of it, you may make an honest man of mee, if it, please you, and when thou hast made mee one, by my Troth Mall Ile keepe my selfe, for I am a Gentle man both by the fathers side and mothers side, and though I haue not the mucke of the world I haue a great deale of good Loue, and I prethee accept of it.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: M. Deane.
Doe you know this Gentlemans businesse to me.

sp.speaker: Now.
sp.l: Not I, beleeue me Madam.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: I shall haue her sure: why ile tell you Sir, my Lady here is a comely, ancient, rich widow, & I am a honest, propper, poore young man, remembring stil I am a Gentleman, now what good her riches may doe to her pouertie, your grauetie may gesse: saue a soule perhaps M. Deane, looke you sir, it is but giuing my hand into hers, and hers into mine: M. Deane, I protest before God shee hath my heart already, and with some three or foure words which I know you haue by rote, make vs two my Ladie and I, one till death vs depart.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: This Gentleman thinks that to be a matter of nothing. But doe you loue me as you doe protest?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Loue you Madam loue you by this hand: I shall haue her sure, friends you see how the businesse goes forward, bring me your billes to morow morning or vpon the hope that I haue, you may leaue them with me, I shall be able to discharge; Ha, ha, Iacke.

sp.speaker: Ladie.
sp.p: How will you maintaine me Sir, if I should marry you?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Maintaine, what needst thou aske that question?
Foote thou hast maintenance ynough for thee and I too.
sp.p: If I should marry you? Friends, you see how it goes now, to morrow within an houre after I am married, I must take the vpper hand of my Vncle, and the next Sunday I that was scarce worthy to fit in the Belferie, the Church-wardens fetch me, and seat me in the Chauncell.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: M. Deane, I protest, neuer since I was widow,
Neuer did man make so much loue to me.
Sir for your loue, I am much beholding to you.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: Doe Mall, prethee doe not thinke it so, be chosen one of the common Counsell, or one of the Masters of the Hospitall, so perhaps I shall neuer become it, marrie if I should bee chosen one of the Maisters of Bridewell, for some of my old acquaintance; fut, I would take it vpon me, vice must be corrected, vice must be corrected.

sp.speaker: La: Ram:
sp.l: Fill me a large cup full of Hippocrist,
And bring me hither 20. li. in gold.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: And one of your husbands Liuery Gownes, so now you trouble your selfe so much, that gold is to contract vs withall: a simple morning: Friends, you cannot beat me downe with your bils. M. Deane of Poules I pray you stay and dine with me you shall not say mee nay, the oftner you come, the more welcome.

sp.speaker: Now.
sp.l: You are merry sir. (cause,

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: I thanke God, and all the world may see I haue no other
That I am likely to be so well bestowed.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Sir, you shall not say the loue you shew'd to me,
Was entertain'd but with kind curtesie:
This for your loue, vnto your health I drinke.
Pledge me.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: I by my Torth Mall will I, weare it as deepe as a well.

sp.speaker: Ladie.
sp.l: Now for your paines there is twentie pound in gold.
Nay, take the Cuppe too sir, thanks for your loue:
And were my thought's bent vnto marriage,
I rather would with you that seeme thus wild,
Then one that hath worse thoughts and seemes moe mild.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Foote will you not haue me then?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Yes, when I meane to marry any one,
And that not whilst I liue.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: See how a man may bee deceiued: I thought I should haue beene sure by this time well, though I shall not haue you, I shall haue this with a good will.

sp.speaker: Ladie.
sp.l: With all my heart, and for the Loue you haue showne,
Wish it to thriue with you euen as mine owne.
To Morrow shall we attend your worship.
Sir her's my bill, it comes to twentie pound.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Friends, Ploydens Prouerbe, The Case is altered and by my troth I haue learn'd you a Lesson, Forbearance is no Acquittance.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: What men are these?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Faith Madam, men that haue my hand, though not for my honesty, yet for the money that I owe them.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: What doth he owe you?
Fiftie pound, Madame.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: What you?
A hundred Markes.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Ile pay you both: and sir to doe you good,
To all your Creditors Ile doe the like.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: That's said like a kinde wench,
And though we neuer meet againe,
We will haue one Busse more at parting:
And now I faith I haue all my wilde oates sowen,
And if I can grow rich by the helpe of this,
Ile say I rose by Lady Ramsies kisse.
sp.stage: Enter Queene, Hunsdon, Lecester, Drum, Colours, and Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.p: A stand there Lords. Whence comes this sound of shot?

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: Please it your Maiestie, t'is thought the Fleet
Lately discouered by your Subiect Flemming,
Riding along the Coasts of France and Dunkerke,
Is met and fought with by your Admirall.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Heauen prosper his proceedings; harke my Lords,
Stil it increaseth: Oh had God and Nature,
Giuen vs proportion man-like to our mind,
Wee'd not stand here fenc't in a wall of Armes,
But haue beene present in these Sea a larmes.

sp.speaker: Huns.
sp.l: Your royall resolution, hath created
New spirits in your souldiers brests, and made
Of one man three.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Make way there, whats the newes,

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: Your Royall Fleet bids battel to the Spaniards,
Whose number with the aduantage of the wind,
Giues them great oddes but the vndaunted worth,
And well knowne valour of your Admirall,
Sir Francis Drake, and Martin Furbisher
Giues vs assured hope of victorie.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Where did the royall Nauies first incounter?

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: From Douer Cliffes we might discerne them ioyne,
But such a cloud of smoke inuiron'd them,
We could discouer nought of their proceedings:
For the great Spanish Fleet had wind and Tide,
God and good hearts stand on your Graces side.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Ther's for thy newes: he that first lent me breath,
Stand in the right of wrong'd Elizabeth.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: God and his Angels, for Elizabeth.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Welcome a Gods name, what's the newes my friend,
Alas, good man: his lookes speakes for his tongue.
How stands the sea-fight.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: Much contrarious.
The Spanish Fleet cast in a warlike Ranke
Like a halfe Moone, or to a full bent bow,
Wait for aduantage: when amongst the rest
Sir Martin Furbisher blinded with smoke,
And fir'd in heart with emulating honour,
Gaue the proud Spaniard a broad side of shot:
But being within the compasse of their danger,
The distant corners of the gripled Fleet
Circled him round: this valiant Furbisher,
With all his braue and gallant followers,
Are foulded in deaths armes.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: If he Surviue,
He shall be nobly ransomed: If he die,
He liues an honour to his Nation.
How fares our Admirall?

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: Brauely he fights,
Directs with iudgement and with heedfull care,
Offends the Foe: England nere bred
Men that at sea fight better managed.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: It cheers my blood and if my God be pleased
For some neclected dutie in our selfe,
To punish vs with losse of them at sea,
His will be done: yet will we pray for them.
If they returne, our selfe will be the first
Will bid them welcome: what saves valiant Lecester?
Thou wilt not leaue me wilt thou? dost thou looke pale?
What sayes olde Hunsdon? nay ile speake thy part,
Thy hand old Lord, I am sure I haue thy heart.

sp.speaker: Huns.
sp.l: Both hand and hart.
sp.stage: A noyse within crying a Furbisher.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Then let both heart and hand,
Be brauely vs'd in honour of our Land.
Before thou speakest take that if he be dead,
A Queene will see his Funerall honoured.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: When the foes ships
Had grasp't his ships within a steely girdle,
The valiant Captaine ouer-charg'd with her,
Hauing no roome for cowardize or feare,
Gaue all his ordinance a gallant charge,
Cheer'd vp his souldiers, man'd vp his fights,
And standing bare-head, brauely on the decke,
When dangerous shot as thicke as April haile
Dropt by his eares, he waued his war-like sword,
And with a bold defiance the foe.
The watch-word giuen, his Ordinance let flie
With such a furie, that it broke their rankes,
Shotter'd their sides and made their war-like shippes
Like drunkards reele, and tumble side to side:
But to conclude such was the will of heauen,
The true spirit of that Gentle-man,
That being thought hopelesse to be preserued,
Yet in warres despite and all the Spaniards scoffe,
He brought his ship and souldiers brauely off.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Warres spight indeed, and we to doe him right,
The shippe he sailde in, fought in, cal'd Warres spight.
Now noble souldiers rouze your hearts like me,
To noble resolution: if any heere
There be that loue vs not, or harbour feare;
Wee giue him libertie to leaue our Campe
Without displeasure.
Our Armies royall so be equall our hearts,
For with the meanest heere ile spend my blood,
And so to loose it count my onely good.
A March, laed on: wee'le meet the worst can fall,
A mayden Queene will be your Generall.
sp.stage: They march one way out, at the other doore enter Sir Francis Drake with Colours, and Ensignes taken from the Spaniards.
sp.l: What meane these Spannish Ensignes in the hands
Of English Subiects?

sp.speaker: Drake.
sp.l: Honourable Queene,
They shew that Spaniards liues are in the hands
Of Englands Soueraigne.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Englands God be prais'd
But prethe Drake, for well I knowe thy name,
And ile not be vnmindfull of thy worth:
Breefly rehearse the danger of the battle,
Till Furbisher was rescued wee haue heard.

sp.speaker: Drake.
sp.l: The danger after that was worse than then:
Valour a both sides stroue to rise with honour,
As is a paire of Ballance once made euen,
So stood the day, inclin'd to neither side:
Sometimes we yeelded, but like a Ramme
That makes returnement to redouble strength;
Then forc't them yeeld when our Lord Admirall
Following the chase: Pedro their Admirall,
With many Knights and Captaines of account,
Were by his noble deeds tane prisoners,
And vnder his Conduct are safely kept:
And are by this time landed at S. Margrets:
From whence they meane to march along by land,
And at S. Iames hee'le greet your Maiestie.
These Spannish Ensignes tokens of our Conquest,
Our Captaines tooke from off their battered ships:
Such as stood out we sunke, such as submitted,
Tasted our English mercie, and mercie
Vassals and prisoners to your Soueraigntie.

sp.speaker: Quée.
sp.l: Next vnder God, your valors haue the praise:
Dismisse our Campe, and tread a royall March
Towards S. Iames, where in martiall order
Wee'le meete and parley our Lord Admirall,
And set a ransome of his Prisoners.
As for those Ensignes see them safely kept,
And giue commandement to the Deane of Powles,
He not forget in his next learned Sermon,
To celebrate this conquest at Powles Crosse:
And to the Audience in our name declare.
Our thankes to heauen in vniuersall Prayer:
For tho our enemies be ouerthrowne,
Tis by the hand of heauen, and not our owne.
On: Sound a call; Now louing Countreymen,
Subiects, and fellow souldiers, that haue left
Your weeping wiues, your goods and children,
And layd your liues vpon the edge of death,
For good of England, and Elizabeth,
We thanke you all: those that for vs would bleed,
Shall finde vs kinde to them and to their seed.
Wee heare dismisse you and dismisse our Campe.
Againe we thanke you: pleaseth God we liue,
A greater recompence then thankes wee'le giue.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Our liues, and liuings for Elizabeth.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Thankes; generall thankes.
Towards London march we to a peacefull throne,
We wish no warres, yet we must guard our owne.
